Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Transcriber: Andrea McDonough
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar A couple of years ago I started using Twitter, and one of the things that really charmed me about Twitter is that people would wake up in the morning and they would say, "Good morning!" which I thought, I'm a Canadian, so I was a little bit, I liked that politeness. And so, I'm also a giant nerd, and so I wrote a computer program that would record 24 hours of everybody on Twitter saying, "Good morning!" And then I asked myself my favorite question, "What would that look like?" Well, as it turns out, I think it would look something like this. Right, so we'd see this wave of people saying, "Good morning!" across the world as they wake up. Now the green people, these are people that wake up at around 8 o'clock in the morning, Who wakes up at 8 o'clock or says, "Good morning!" at 8? And the orange people, they say, "Good morning!" around 9. And the red people, they say, "Good morning!" around 10. Yeah, more at 10's than, more at 10's than 8's. And actually if you look at this map, we can learn a little bit about how people wake up in different parts of the world. People on the West Coast, for example, they wake up a little bit later than those people on the East Coast. But that's not all that people say on Twitter, right? We also get these really important tweets, like, "I just landed in Orlando!! [plane sign, plane sign]" Or, or, "I just landed in Texas [exclamation point]!" Or "I just landed in Honduras!" These lists, they go on and on and on, all these people, right? So, on the outside, these people are just telling us something about how they're traveling. But we know the truth, don't we? These people are show-offs! They are showing off that they're in Cape Town and I'm not. So I thought, how can we take this vanity and turn it into utility? So using a similar approach that I did with "Good morning," I mapped all those people's trips because I know where they're landing, they just told me, and I know where they live because they share that information on their Twitter profile. So what I'm able to do with 36 hours of Twitter is create a model of how people are traveling around the world during that 36 hours. And this is kind of a prototype because I think if we listen to everybody on Twitter and Facebook and the rest of our social media, we'd actually get a pretty clear picture of how people are traveling from one place to the other, which is actually turns out to be a very useful thing for scientists, particularly those who are studying how disease is spread. So, I work upstairs in the New York Times, and for the last two years, we've been working on a project called, "Cascade," which in some ways is kind of similar to this one. But instead of modeling how people move, we're modeling how people talk. We're looking at what does a discussion look like. Well, here's an example. This is a discussion around an article called, "The Island Where People Forget to Die". It's about an island in Greece where people live a really, really, really, really, really, really long time. And what we're seeing here is we're seeing a conversation that's stemming from that first tweet down in the bottom, left-hand corner. So we get to see the scope of this conversation over about 9 hours right now, we're going to creep up to 12 hours here in a second. But, we can also see what that conversation looks like in three dimensions. And that three-dimensional view is actually much more useful for us. As humans, we are really used to things that are structured as three dimensions. So, we can look at those little off-shoots of conversation, we can find out what exactly happened. And this is an interactive, exploratory tool so we can go through every step in the conversation. We can look at who the people were, what they said, how old they are, where they live, who follows them, and so on, and so on, and so on. So, the Times creates about 6,500 pieces of content every month, and we can model every single one of the conversations that happen around them. And they look somewhat different. Depending on the story and depending on how fast people are talking about it and how far the conversation spreads, these structures, which I call these conversational architectures, end up looking different. So, these projects that I've shown you, I think they all involve the same thing: we can take small pieces of data and by putting them together, we can generate more value, we can do more exciting things with them. But so far we've only talked about Twitter, right? And Twitter isn't all the data. We learned a moment ago that there is tons and tons, tons more data out there. And specifically, I want you to think about one type of data because all of you guys, everybody in this audience, we, we, me as well, are data-making machines. We are producing data all the time. Every single one of us, we're producing data. Somebody else, though, is storing that data. Usually we put our trust into companies to store that data, but what I want to suggest here is that rather than putting our trust in companies to store that data, we should put the trust in ourselves because we actually own that data. Right, that is something we should remember. Everything that someone else measures about you, you actually own. So, it's my hope, maybe because I'm a Canadian, that all of us can come together with this really valuable data that we've been storing, and we can collectively launch that data toward some of the world's most difficulty problems because big data can solve big problems, but I think it can do it the best if it's all of us who are in control. Thank you.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: According to Thorp's map of people saying good morning, who sleeps until later in the day?
Options: A. New York City, B. East Coast, C. West Coast, D. Midwest
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What inspired the speaker to write a computer program that would record 24 hours of everybody on Twitter saying, "Good morning!"? Options: A. The speaker was charmed by the politeness of people on Twitter and wanted to analyze their social behavior., B. The speaker was interested in the social behavior of people on Twitter., C. The speaker was trying to create a new social media platform., D. The speaker wanted to analyze how people wake up around the world. Correct Option: A
Question 2: What can be learned from the map of people saying, "Good morning!" on Twitter? Options: A. People on the West Coast wake up later than those on the East Coast., B. People in different parts of the world wake up at the same time., C. People on Twitter wake up at random times., D. People on Twitter don't say, "Good morning!" at all. Correct Option: A
Question 3: What is the main idea of the speaker's project "Cascade"? Options: A. Modeling how people move around the world., B. Modeling how people talk and have conversations., C. Analyzing how people use social media., D. Creating a new social media platform. Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is a conversational architecture? Options: A. A map of people saying, "Good morning!" on Twitter., B. A structure that shows how people talk and have conversations., C. A way to analyze how people use social media., D. A new social media platform. Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the main idea of the speaker's message about data ownership? Options: A. We should trust companies to store our data., B. We should put our trust in ourselves to store our data., C. We should ignore data ownership altogether., D. We should sell our data to companies. Correct Option: B
Question 6: What can big data solve? Options: A. Small problems., B. Big problems., C. No problems at all., D. Only social media-related problems. Correct Option: B
Question 7: According to the speaker, what are we as humans used to? Options: A. Things that are structured in two dimensions., B. Things that are structured in three dimensions., C. Things that are structured in one dimension., D. Things that are not structured at all. Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the name of the project that the speaker works on at the New York Times? Options: A. "Cascade"., B. "Good Morning"., C. "Data Ownership"., D. "Social Media Analysis". Correct Option: A
Question 9: How many pieces of content does the New York Times create every month? Options: A. 1,000., B. 6,500., C. 10,000., D. 20,000. Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the main idea of the speaker's message about collective action? Options: A. We should work alone to solve problems., B. We should work together to solve problems., C. We should ignore problems altogether., D. We should sell our data to companies to solve problems. Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is:

**Question 2: What can be learned from the map of people saying, "Good morning!" on Twitter? Options: A. People on the West Coast wake up later than those on the East Coast., B. People in different parts of the world wake up at the same time., C. People on Twitter wake up at random times., D. People on Twitter don't say, "Good morning!" at all. Correct Option: A**

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. Both questions are asking about the pattern of people waking up in different parts of the world, and both have options that mention the West Coast and East Coast.

The index of the most similar generated MCQ is: **2**

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Transcriber: Andrea McDonough
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar A couple of years ago I started using Twitter, and one of the things that really charmed me about Twitter is that people would wake up in the morning and they would say, "Good morning!" which I thought, I'm a Canadian, so I was a little bit, I liked that politeness. And so, I'm also a giant nerd, and so I wrote a computer program that would record 24 hours of everybody on Twitter saying, "Good morning!" And then I asked myself my favorite question, "What would that look like?" Well, as it turns out, I think it would look something like this. Right, so we'd see this wave of people saying, "Good morning!" across the world as they wake up. Now the green people, these are people that wake up at around 8 o'clock in the morning, Who wakes up at 8 o'clock or says, "Good morning!" at 8? And the orange people, they say, "Good morning!" around 9. And the red people, they say, "Good morning!" around 10. Yeah, more at 10's than, more at 10's than 8's. And actually if you look at this map, we can learn a little bit about how people wake up in different parts of the world. People on the West Coast, for example, they wake up a little bit later than those people on the East Coast. But that's not all that people say on Twitter, right? We also get these really important tweets, like, "I just landed in Orlando!! [plane sign, plane sign]" Or, or, "I just landed in Texas [exclamation point]!" Or "I just landed in Honduras!" These lists, they go on and on and on, all these people, right? So, on the outside, these people are just telling us something about how they're traveling. But we know the truth, don't we? These people are show-offs! They are showing off that they're in Cape Town and I'm not. So I thought, how can we take this vanity and turn it into utility? So using a similar approach that I did with "Good morning," I mapped all those people's trips because I know where they're landing, they just told me, and I know where they live because they share that information on their Twitter profile. So what I'm able to do with 36 hours of Twitter is create a model of how people are traveling around the world during that 36 hours. And this is kind of a prototype because I think if we listen to everybody on Twitter and Facebook and the rest of our social media, we'd actually get a pretty clear picture of how people are traveling from one place to the other, which is actually turns out to be a very useful thing for scientists, particularly those who are studying how disease is spread. So, I work upstairs in the New York Times, and for the last two years, we've been working on a project called, "Cascade," which in some ways is kind of similar to this one. But instead of modeling how people move, we're modeling how people talk. We're looking at what does a discussion look like. Well, here's an example. This is a discussion around an article called, "The Island Where People Forget to Die". It's about an island in Greece where people live a really, really, really, really, really, really long time. And what we're seeing here is we're seeing a conversation that's stemming from that first tweet down in the bottom, left-hand corner. So we get to see the scope of this conversation over about 9 hours right now, we're going to creep up to 12 hours here in a second. But, we can also see what that conversation looks like in three dimensions. And that three-dimensional view is actually much more useful for us. As humans, we are really used to things that are structured as three dimensions. So, we can look at those little off-shoots of conversation, we can find out what exactly happened. And this is an interactive, exploratory tool so we can go through every step in the conversation. We can look at who the people were, what they said, how old they are, where they live, who follows them, and so on, and so on, and so on. So, the Times creates about 6,500 pieces of content every month, and we can model every single one of the conversations that happen around them. And they look somewhat different. Depending on the story and depending on how fast people are talking about it and how far the conversation spreads, these structures, which I call these conversational architectures, end up looking different. So, these projects that I've shown you, I think they all involve the same thing: we can take small pieces of data and by putting them together, we can generate more value, we can do more exciting things with them. But so far we've only talked about Twitter, right? And Twitter isn't all the data. We learned a moment ago that there is tons and tons, tons more data out there. And specifically, I want you to think about one type of data because all of you guys, everybody in this audience, we, we, me as well, are data-making machines. We are producing data all the time. Every single one of us, we're producing data. Somebody else, though, is storing that data. Usually we put our trust into companies to store that data, but what I want to suggest here is that rather than putting our trust in companies to store that data, we should put the trust in ourselves because we actually own that data. Right, that is something we should remember. Everything that someone else measures about you, you actually own. So, it's my hope, maybe because I'm a Canadian, that all of us can come together with this really valuable data that we've been storing, and we can collectively launch that data toward some of the world's most difficulty problems because big data can solve big problems, but I think it can do it the best if it's all of us who are in control. Thank you.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: About how much content does the New York Times create every month?
Options: A. 100 pieces, B. 1 million pieces, C. 6,500 pieces, D. 1,000 pieces
Correct Option: C

**Transcript**:
Transcriber: Andrea McDonough
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar A couple of years ago I started using Twitter, and one of the things that really charmed me about Twitter is that people would wake up in the morning and they would say, "Good morning!" which I thought, I'm a Canadian, so I was a little bit, I liked that politeness. And so, I'm also a giant nerd, and so I wrote a computer program that would record 24 hours of everybody on Twitter saying, "Good morning!" And then I asked myself my favorite question, "What would that look like?" Well, as it turns out, I think it would look something like this. Right, so we'd see this wave of people saying, "Good morning!" across the world as they wake up. Now the green people, these are people that wake up at around 8 o'clock in the morning, Who wakes up at 8 o'clock or says, "Good morning!" at 8? And the orange people, they say, "Good morning!" around 9. And the red people, they say, "Good morning!" around 10. Yeah, more at 10's than, more at 10's than 8's. And actually if you look at this map, we can learn a little bit about how people wake up in different parts of the world. People on the West Coast, for example, they wake up a little bit later than those people on the East Coast. But that's not all that people say on Twitter, right? We also get these really important tweets, like, "I just landed in Orlando!! [plane sign, plane sign]" Or, or, "I just landed in Texas [exclamation point]!" Or "I just landed in Honduras!" These lists, they go on and on and on, all these people, right? So, on the outside, these people are just telling us something about how they're traveling. But we know the truth, don't we? These people are show-offs! They are showing off that they're in Cape Town and I'm not. So I thought, how can we take this vanity and turn it into utility? So using a similar approach that I did with "Good morning," I mapped all those people's trips because I know where they're landing, they just told me, and I know where they live because they share that information on their Twitter profile. So what I'm able to do with 36 hours of Twitter is create a model of how people are traveling around the world during that 36 hours. And this is kind of a prototype because I think if we listen to everybody on Twitter and Facebook and the rest of our social media, we'd actually get a pretty clear picture of how people are traveling from one place to the other, which is actually turns out to be a very useful thing for scientists, particularly those who are studying how disease is spread. So, I work upstairs in the New York Times, and for the last two years, we've been working on a project called, "Cascade," which in some ways is kind of similar to this one. But instead of modeling how people move, we're modeling how people talk. We're looking at what does a discussion look like. Well, here's an example. This is a discussion around an article called, "The Island Where People Forget to Die". It's about an island in Greece where people live a really, really, really, really, really, really long time. And what we're seeing here is we're seeing a conversation that's stemming from that first tweet down in the bottom, left-hand corner. So we get to see the scope of this conversation over about 9 hours right now, we're going to creep up to 12 hours here in a second. But, we can also see what that conversation looks like in three dimensions. And that three-dimensional view is actually much more useful for us. As humans, we are really used to things that are structured as three dimensions. So, we can look at those little off-shoots of conversation, we can find out what exactly happened. And this is an interactive, exploratory tool so we can go through every step in the conversation. We can look at who the people were, what they said, how old they are, where they live, who follows them, and so on, and so on, and so on. So, the Times creates about 6,500 pieces of content every month, and we can model every single one of the conversations that happen around them. And they look somewhat different. Depending on the story and depending on how fast people are talking about it and how far the conversation spreads, these structures, which I call these conversational architectures, end up looking different. So, these projects that I've shown you, I think they all involve the same thing: we can take small pieces of data and by putting them together, we can generate more value, we can do more exciting things with them. But so far we've only talked about Twitter, right? And Twitter isn't all the data. We learned a moment ago that there is tons and tons, tons more data out there. And specifically, I want you to think about one type of data because all of you guys, everybody in this audience, we, we, me as well, are data-making machines. We are producing data all the time. Every single one of us, we're producing data. Somebody else, though, is storing that data. Usually we put our trust into companies to store that data, but what I want to suggest here is that rather than putting our trust in companies to store that data, we should put the trust in ourselves because we actually own that data. Right, that is something we should remember. Everything that someone else measures about you, you actually own. So, it's my hope, maybe because I'm a Canadian, that all of us can come together with this really valuable data that we've been storing, and we can collectively launch that data toward some of the world's most difficulty problems because big data can solve big problems, but I think it can do it the best if it's all of us who are in control. Thank you.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: According to Thorp, you own data that's gathered:
Options: A. Anytime somebody measures something about you, B. When the government enlists you to be involved in a study, C. Only in a study that you conduct yourself, D. That doesn't include any information based on variables outside of yourself or your personal property
Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Transcriber: Andrea McDonough
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar Fourth and nineteen, folks, they've gotta have a play as time's ticking away because they've got to stay in this ball game, they've got to win. They come out lined up in the empty set, three receivers to the right, two to the left. Defense looks like they're gonna to man up with no safety. This is the exact offensive match-up that they want: the best receiver lined up against the linebacker. Quarterback steps back to receive the ball, five yards deep in the gun. He takes a snap, drops three steps, he plants his back foot, he's looking for an opening. There's a blitz coming off the edge! He steps up to avoid the rush. He's looking down field. He's got the inside receiver making a cut. He's got a step on the linebacker. Quarterback has a beat on it. He lets the ball go, it's in the air! Receiver is out in front of the defender. He's got it beat! He's out in front, racing for the ball! It's coming down! He cradles it at the fifteen! He's at the ten, five! Touchdown! Unbelievable play! Now, wait a minute. Of course, it's believable, it's physics, specifically the differences between scalars and vectors. So, let's just see that replay. "Quarterback steps back to receive the ball, five yards deep in the gun." Stop. See, measurements are defined as two different quantities. Scalars are measurements with only numbers, and vectors are measurements with direction. For example, when that quarterback takes the snap, he's five yards away, but from where? Back from the line of scrimmage, so the five yards by itself is a scalar quantity. When you add a direction, like five yards deep, it becomes a vector quantity. Five yards - scalar, five yards deep - vector. OK, go ahead. "He takes a snap, drops three steps. He plants his back foot, he's looking for an opening. There's a blitz coming off the edge! He steps up to avoid the rush." Whoa! Here's a difference between distance and displacement. Distance is a measurement without identifying where you moved. It's a scalar quantity. When the quarterback makes a three-step drop, he moves about three yards back. When he moves about another three yards forward, when he steps up into the pocket, so that quarterback moves a total distance of six yards. That's a distance, that's a scalar. Now, displacement is a vector quantity, describing about how far out of place the object is. So the quarterback dropped back three yards and then moved back forward three yards, he's in the exact same place where he started. So, his displacement is zero yards. Distance - six yards, displacement - zero yards. So, let's look at what happened next. "Quarterback has a beat on it, he let's the ball go! It's in the air! Receiver is out in front of the defender." Stop. So, here's speed and velocity, but let's just do one thing at a time. So, speed is measurement without direction, it's a scalar quantity. Velocity is a vector quantity. It is that object's speed, but with a direction of motion. So the receiver accelerates away, gaining both speed and distance. This takes the receiver 5 seconds to run those 50 yards. So his average speed, in any given time, is 10 yards/second. The linebacker tries to keep up, but his overall speed is slower, he only goes 35 yards in those 5 seconds, so his average speed is only 7 yards/second. They're both traveling in a forward direction, so their velocity is also positive. You can't go from resting to your peak speed immediately. You've got to build up to it. This is acceleration. At first the linebacker can keep up with that receiver, but eventually the faster receiver pulls away. That's acceleration, the change in speed over time. Acceleration is a vector quantity. It describes a rate at which an object changes velocity. Like velocity, acceleration is a vector. It happens in a direction. So let's just look at that play just one more time. "Quarterback steps back to receive the ball, five yards deep in the gun." Vector! "He takes a snap, drops three steps, he plants his back foot. He's looking for an opening. There's a blitz coming off the edge! He steps up to avoid the rush." Displacement! "He's got the inside receiver making a cut. He's got a step on the linebacker. The quarterback has a beat on it. He let's the ball go! It's in the air! Receiver is out in front of the defender!" Velocity! "He's got it beat! He's out in front, racing for the ball! It's coming down! He cradles it at the fifteen, he's at the ten, five!" Acceleration! "Touchdown! Unbelievable play! That was a great play as time expired, resulting in the touchdown and ultimately the win and pure effort." And pure science.

Back from the line of scrimmage, so the five yards by itself is a scalar quantity. When you add a direction, like five yards deep, it becomes a vector quantity. When he moves about another three yards forward, when he steps up into the pocket, so that quarterback moves a total distance of six yards. That's a distance, that's a scalar. Now, displacement is a vector quantity, describing about how far out of place the object is. So the quarterback dropped back three yards and then moved back forward three yards, he's in the exact same place where he started. So, his displacement is zero yards. Distance - six yards, displacement - zero yards. So, let's look at what happened next. "Quarterback has a beat on it, he let's the ball go! It's in the air! Receiver is out in front of the defender." Stop. So, here's speed and velocity, but let's just do one thing at a time. So, speed is measurement without direction, it's a scalar quantity. Velocity is a vector quantity. It is that object's speed, but with a direction of motion. So the receiver accelerates away, gaining both speed and distance. This takes the receiver 5 seconds to run those 50 yards. So his average speed, in any given time, is 10 yards/second. The linebacker tries to keep up, but his overall speed is slower, he only goes 35 yards in those 5 seconds, so his average speed is only 7 yards/second. They're both traveling in a forward direction, so their velocity is also positive. You can't go from resting to your peak speed immediately. You've got to build up to it. This is acceleration. "Quarterback steps back to receive the ball, five yards deep in the gun." Stop. See, measurements are defined as two different quantities. Scalars are measurements with only numbers, and vectors are measurements with direction. For example, when that quarterback takes the snap, he's five yards away, but from where? Back from the line of scrimmage, so the five yards by itself is a scalar quantity. When you add a direction, like five yards deep, it becomes a vector quantity. Five yards - scalar, five yards deep - vector. OK, go ahead. "He takes a snap, drops three steps. He plants his back foot, he's looking for an opening. There's a blitz coming off the edge! He steps up to avoid the rush." Whoa! Here's a difference between distance and displacement. Distance is a measurement without identifying where you moved. It's a scalar quantity. When the quarterback makes a three-step drop, he moves about three yards back. When he moves about another three yards forward, when he steps up into the pocket, so that quarterback moves a total distance of six yards. That's a distance, that's a scalar. Now, displacement is a vector quantity, describing about how far out of place the object is. So the quarterback dropped back three yards and then moved back forward three yards, he's in the exact same place where he started. So, his displacement is zero yards. Distance - six yards, displacement - zero yards. So, let's look at what happened next. "Quarterback has a beat on it, he let's the ball go! It's in the air! Receiver is out in front of the defender." Stop. So, here's speed and velocity, but let's just do one thing at a time. So, speed is measurement without direction, it's a scalar quantity. Velocity is a vector quantity. It is that object's speed, but with a direction of motion. So the receiver accelerates away, gaining both speed and distance. This takes the receiver 5 seconds to run those 50 yards. So his average speed, in any given time, is 10 yards/second. The linebacker tries to keep up, but his overall speed is slower, he only goes 35 yards in those 5 seconds, so his average speed is only 7 yards/second. They're both traveling in a forward direction, so their velocity is also positive. You can't go from resting to your peak speed immediately. You've got to build up to it. This is acceleration. At first the linebacker can keep up with that receiver, but eventually the faster receiver pulls away. That's acceleration, the change in speed over time. Acceleration is a vector quantity. It describes a rate at which an object changes velocity. Like velocity, acceleration is a vector. It happens in a direction. So let's just look at that play just one more time. "Quarterback steps back to receive the ball, five yards deep in the gun." Vector! "He takes a snap, drops three steps, he plants his back foot. He's looking for an opening. There's a blitz coming off the edge! He steps up to avoid the rush." Displacement! "He's got the inside receiver making a cut. He's got a step on the linebacker. The quarterback has a beat on it. He let's the ball go! It's in the air! Receiver is out in front of the defender!" Velocity! "He's got it beat! He's out in front, racing for the ball! It's coming down! He cradles it at the fifteen, he's at the ten, five!" Acceleration! "Touchdown! Unbelievable play! That was a great play as time expired, resulting in the touchdown and ultimately the win and pure effort." And pure science.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What principle describes why you can't go from resting to your peak speed immediately?
Options: A. Velocity, B. Displacement, C. Trajectory, D. Acceleration
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the main difference between a scalar and a vector quantity? Options: A. A scalar is a quantity with magnitude, while a vector is a quantity with magnitude and direction., B. A scalar is a quantity without direction, while a vector is a quantity with direction., C. A scalar is a quantity with magnitude and direction, while a vector is a quantity without magnitude and direction., D. A scalar is a quantity without magnitude, while a vector is a quantity with magnitude. Correct Option: A
Question 2: What is the term for the measurement of an object's speed in a specific direction? Options: A. Speed, B. Acceleration, C. Displacement, D. Velocity Correct Option: D
Question 3: What is the term for the change in an object's speed over time? Options: A. Velocity, B. Acceleration, C. Displacement, D. Distance Correct Option: B
Question 4: In the context of the quarterback's movement, what is the main difference between distance and displacement? Options: A. Distance is a measurement of an object's speed, while displacement is a measurement of an object's direction., B. Distance is a measurement of an object's direction, while displacement is a measurement of an object's speed., C. Distance is a scalar quantity, while displacement is a vector quantity., D. Distance is a vector quantity, while displacement is a scalar quantity. Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is the average speed of the receiver in the given scenario? Options: A. 5 yards/second, B. 7 yards/second, C. 10 yards/second, D. 15 yards/second Correct Option: C
Question 6: What is the term for the rate at which an object changes velocity? Options: A. Velocity, B. Acceleration, C. Displacement, D. Distance Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the main difference between speed and velocity? Options: A. Speed is a measurement of an object's speed, while velocity is a measurement of an object's direction., B. Speed is a measurement of an object's direction, while velocity is a measurement of an object's speed., C. Speed is a scalar quantity, while velocity is a vector quantity., D. Speed is a vector quantity, while velocity is a scalar quantity. Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is the term for the measurement of an object's speed without direction? Options: A. Velocity, B. Acceleration, C. Displacement, D. Speed Correct Option: D
Question 9: In the context of the quarterback's movement, what is the term for the measurement of an object's distance without identifying where it moved? Options: A. Displacement, B. Distance, C. Velocity, D. Acceleration Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the term for the measurement of an object's speed with direction? Options: A. Speed, B. Velocity, C. Acceleration, D. Displacement Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Transcriber: Andrea McDonough
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar Ever see a medieval painting of baby Jesus sitting or standing on his mother's lap and wonder why she's so large? Paintings like Cimabue's enthroned Madonna with angels or Duccio's Maesta also appear out of proportion. If Mary were to stand up, it seems, the angels in the picture would be as tall as her shin bone, and her torso would be disproportionately small when compared to her legs. Maybe you thought the artist simply wasn't skilled enough to paint realistically or lacked the mathematical skill of perspective. But that's not the full story. To understand why, we need to go back to the late fifth century when the city of Rome was attacked by the Goths. Rome was built in marble and meant to last forever. It represented, for many years, the pinnacle of human civilization, so its destruction left a huge void. Theologians, who preached about a world beyond the physical, began attracting an audience as Rome crumbled, and Christianity started to fill the void left by the Empire. As a replacement for the physical beauty of Rome, Christianity offered a metaphysical beauty of virtue and an eternal heaven that could not be destroyed as Rome had. After the fall of Rome, early medieval theologians turned away from physical beauty, rejecting it in favor of inner-beauty. They maintained that while the physical world was temporary, virtue and religion were permanent. Beautiful objects could lead to a misguided worship of the object rather than the worship of goodness. It is said that the early sixth century preacher, St. Benedict, upon thinking of a beautiful woman, threw himself into a thorn patch, and through his suffering, regained his focus on spiritual beauty. He feared his desire for the beautiful woman would distract him from his desire to love God. As European civilization transitioned away from empires and towards religion, monasteries became the gatekeepers of knowledge, which meant that classical books that praised physical pleasures were not copied or protected. Without protection, they became the victims of natural decay, fire, flooding, or pests. And without the help of monks transcribing new copies, these texts and the philosophies they carried disappeared in Western Europe and were replaced by the works of people like St. Benedict, which brings us back to these depictions of Jesus and Mary. Because Christianity had so fervently rejected physical beauty, these medieval artists purposefully avoided aesthetically pleasing forms. At first, decorations for churches or palaces were limited to interesting geometric patterns, which could be pleasing without inspiring sinful thoughts of physical pleasure. As the medieval period progressed, depictions of Jesus and Mary were tolerated, but the artist clearly made an effort to veil Mary and give her disproportionately large legs, with those enormous shin bones. The fear remained that a beautiful illustration of Mary might inspire the viewer to love the painting or the physical form of Mary, rather than the virtue she's meant to represent. So even though it may be fun to think we can paint more realistically than Cimabuey or Duccio, we need to remember that they had different goals when picking up a paintbrush.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What prominent figure in Medieval paintings was commonly painted out of proportion?
Options: A. Mary, the mother of Jesus, B. David, the shepherd boy, C. Gabriel, the angel, D. Venus, the Roman goddess
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is a common feature in medieval paintings of baby Jesus and his mother Mary? Options: A. They often depict Mary as having disproportionately large legs and small torso., B. The paintings feature a realistic representation of the mother and child., C. Jesus is typically shown standing on a pedestal., D. The background of the paintings often features modern-day landscapes. Correct Option: A
Question 2: What event in the 5th century led to a significant change in European society? Options: A. The rise of Christianity., B. The fall of the Roman Empire., C. The discovery of the New World., D. The invention of the printing press. Correct Option: B
Question 3: According to the transcript, what was the primary concern of early medieval theologians regarding physical beauty? Options: A. They believed it was essential for spiritual growth., B. They feared it would distract people from worshiping God., C. They thought it was a necessary aspect of art., D. They saw it as a way to connect with the divine. Correct Option: B
Question 4: How did the fall of the Roman Empire affect the preservation of classical texts? Options: A. They were more likely to be copied and protected., B. They were less likely to be copied and protected., C. They were destroyed immediately., D. They were left untouched. Correct Option: B
Question 5: What was the goal of medieval artists when depicting Jesus and Mary in a way that avoided aesthetically pleasing forms? Options: A. To create a sense of realism., B. To inspire sinful thoughts of physical pleasure., C. To focus attention on the virtue they represented., D. To create a sense of drama. Correct Option: C
Question 6: What can be inferred about the role of monasteries in preserving knowledge during the medieval period? Options: A. They were primarily responsible for destroying classical texts., B. They played a minor role in preserving knowledge., C. They were the primary gatekeepers of knowledge., D. They had no influence on the preservation of knowledge. Correct Option: C
Question 7: How did the fear of physical beauty influence the depiction of Jesus and Mary in medieval art? Options: A. It led to more realistic portrayals., B. It resulted in the use of brighter colors., C. It led to the avoidance of aesthetically pleasing forms., D. It had no impact on the depiction of Jesus and Mary. Correct Option: C
Question 8: What can be inferred about the values of early medieval society based on the transcript? Options: A. They valued physical beauty above all else., B. They valued spiritual beauty above all else., C. They had no particular values., D. They valued material wealth above all else. Correct Option: B
Question 9: What can be inferred about the role of St. Benedict in the development of medieval art and society? Options: A. He was a major influence on the development of classical art., B. He played a minor role in the development of medieval art and society., C. He was a key figure in the rejection of physical beauty in art., D. He had no influence on the development of medieval art and society. Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the significance of the story of St. Benedict and the beautiful woman in the context of the transcript? Options: A. It illustrates the importance of physical beauty in art., B. It highlights the dangers of being distracted by physical beauty., C. It has no significance in the context of the transcript., D. It shows the power of physical beauty to inspire spiritual growth. Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 1. 

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent (identifying a common feature in medieval paintings of a prominent figure), options (specifically mentioning Mary, the mother of Jesus), and content (discussing the depiction of Mary in medieval paintings).

Transcriber: Andrea McDonough
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar Ever see a medieval painting of baby Jesus sitting or standing on his mother's lap and wonder why she's so large? Paintings like Cimabue's enthroned Madonna with angels or Duccio's Maesta also appear out of proportion. If Mary were to stand up, it seems, the angels in the picture would be as tall as her shin bone, and her torso would be disproportionately small when compared to her legs. Maybe you thought the artist simply wasn't skilled enough to paint realistically or lacked the mathematical skill of perspective. But that's not the full story. To understand why, we need to go back to the late fifth century when the city of Rome was attacked by the Goths. Rome was built in marble and meant to last forever. It represented, for many years, the pinnacle of human civilization, so its destruction left a huge void. Theologians, who preached about a world beyond the physical, began attracting an audience as Rome crumbled, and Christianity started to fill the void left by the Empire. As a replacement for the physical beauty of Rome, Christianity offered a metaphysical beauty of virtue and an eternal heaven that could not be destroyed as Rome had. After the fall of Rome, early medieval theologians turned away from physical beauty, rejecting it in favor of inner-beauty. They maintained that while the physical world was temporary, virtue and religion were permanent. Beautiful objects could lead to a misguided worship of the object rather than the worship of goodness. He feared his desire for the beautiful woman would distract him from his desire to love God. As European civilization transitioned away from empires and towards religion, monasteries became the gatekeepers of knowledge, which meant that classical books that praised physical pleasures were not copied or protected. Without protection, they became the victims of natural decay, fire, flooding, or pests. And without the help of monks transcribing new copies, these texts and the philosophies they carried disappeared in Western Europe and were replaced by the works of people like St. Benedict, which brings us back to these depictions of Jesus and Mary. At first, decorations for churches or palaces were limited to interesting geometric patterns, which could be pleasing without inspiring sinful thoughts of physical pleasure. As the medieval period progressed, depictions of Jesus and Mary were tolerated, but the artist clearly made an effort to veil Mary and give her disproportionately large legs, with those enormous shin bones. The fear remained that a beautiful illustration of Mary might inspire the viewer to love the painting or the physical form of Mary, rather than the virtue she's meant to represent. So even though it may be fun to think we can paint more realistically than Cimabuey or Duccio, we need to remember that they had different goals when picking up a paintbrush.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What did Christianity offer in place of the crumbling Roman empire?
Options: A. A metaphysical beauty of virtue, B. An eternal heaven that could not be destroyed as Rome had, C. Protection from invading countries, D. Both A and B
Correct Option: D

Question: What first populated art spaces in churches and palaces after the fall of Rome?
Options: A. Solid colors that represented the deadly sins and the holy virtues, B. Country landscapes that reminded parishioners of peace, C. Interesting geometric patterns that lacked a semblance of physical beauty, D. Depictions of stories from scripture, especially those from the first five books of the Bible

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Transcriber: Andrea McDonough
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar Ever see a medieval painting of baby Jesus sitting or standing on his mother's lap and wonder why she's so large? Paintings like Cimabue's enthroned Madonna with angels or Duccio's Maesta also appear out of proportion. If Mary were to stand up, it seems, the angels in the picture would be as tall as her shin bone, and her torso would be disproportionately small when compared to her legs. Maybe you thought the artist simply wasn't skilled enough to paint realistically or lacked the mathematical skill of perspective. But that's not the full story. To understand why, we need to go back to the late fifth century when the city of Rome was attacked by the Goths. Rome was built in marble and meant to last forever. It represented, for many years, the pinnacle of human civilization, so its destruction left a huge void. Theologians, who preached about a world beyond the physical, began attracting an audience as Rome crumbled, and Christianity started to fill the void left by the Empire. As a replacement for the physical beauty of Rome, Christianity offered a metaphysical beauty of virtue and an eternal heaven that could not be destroyed as Rome had. After the fall of Rome, early medieval theologians turned away from physical beauty, rejecting it in favor of inner-beauty. They maintained that while the physical world was temporary, virtue and religion were permanent. Beautiful objects could lead to a misguided worship of the object rather than the worship of goodness. It is said that the early sixth century preacher, St. Benedict, upon thinking of a beautiful woman, threw himself into a thorn patch, and through his suffering, regained his focus on spiritual beauty. He feared his desire for the beautiful woman would distract him from his desire to love God. As European civilization transitioned away from empires and towards religion, monasteries became the gatekeepers of knowledge, which meant that classical books that praised physical pleasures were not copied or protected. Without protection, they became the victims of natural decay, fire, flooding, or pests. And without the help of monks transcribing new copies, these texts and the philosophies they carried disappeared in Western Europe and were replaced by the works of people like St. Benedict, which brings us back to these depictions of Jesus and Mary. Because Christianity had so fervently rejected physical beauty, these medieval artists purposefully avoided aesthetically pleasing forms. At first, decorations for churches or palaces were limited to interesting geometric patterns, which could be pleasing without inspiring sinful thoughts of physical pleasure. As the medieval period progressed, depictions of Jesus and Mary were tolerated, but the artist clearly made an effort to veil Mary and give her disproportionately large legs, with those enormous shin bones. The fear remained that a beautiful illustration of Mary might inspire the viewer to love the painting or the physical form of Mary, rather than the virtue she's meant to represent. So even though it may be fun to think we can paint more realistically than Cimabuey or Duccio, we need to remember that they had different goals when picking up a paintbrush.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What's the best reason (or the best reasons) Cimabue and Duccio painted a veiled, disproportionate Mary?
Options: A. They had a different goal in mind when painting, B. They didn't want to tempt people to worship the painting instead of the virtue it represented, C. They realized that Mary was not entirely mortal, as she was chosen by God, therefore must be represented differently in paintings, D. Both A and B
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is a common feature in medieval paintings of baby Jesus and his mother Mary? Options: A. They often depict Mary as having disproportionately large legs and small torso., B. The paintings feature a realistic representation of the mother and child., C. Jesus is typically shown standing on a pedestal., D. The background of the paintings often features modern-day landscapes. Correct Option: A
Question 2: What event in the 5th century led to a significant change in European society? Options: A. The rise of Christianity., B. The fall of the Roman Empire., C. The discovery of the New World., D. The invention of the printing press. Correct Option: B
Question 3: According to the transcript, what was the primary concern of early medieval theologians regarding physical beauty? Options: A. They believed it was essential for spiritual growth., B. They feared it would distract people from worshiping God., C. They thought it was a necessary aspect of art., D. They saw it as a way to connect with the divine. Correct Option: B
Question 4: How did the fall of the Roman Empire affect the preservation of classical texts? Options: A. They were more likely to be copied and protected., B. They were less likely to be copied and protected., C. They were destroyed immediately., D. They were left untouched. Correct Option: B
Question 5: What was the goal of medieval artists when depicting Jesus and Mary in a way that avoided aesthetically pleasing forms? Options: A. To create a sense of realism., B. To inspire sinful thoughts of physical pleasure., C. To focus attention on the virtue they represented., D. To create a sense of drama. Correct Option: C
Question 6: What can be inferred about the role of monasteries in preserving knowledge during the medieval period? Options: A. They were primarily responsible for destroying classical texts., B. They played a minor role in preserving knowledge., C. They were the primary gatekeepers of knowledge., D. They had no influence on the preservation of knowledge. Correct Option: C
Question 7: How did the fear of physical beauty influence the depiction of Jesus and Mary in medieval art? Options: A. It led to more realistic portrayals., B. It resulted in the use of brighter colors., C. It led to the avoidance of aesthetically pleasing forms., D. It had no impact on the depiction of Jesus and Mary. Correct Option: C
Question 8: What can be inferred about the values of early medieval society based on the transcript? Options: A. They valued physical beauty above all else., B. They valued spiritual beauty above all else., C. They had no particular values., D. They valued material wealth above all else. Correct Option: B
Question 9: What can be inferred about the role of St. Benedict in the development of medieval art and society? Options: A. He was a major influence on the development of classical art., B. He played a minor role in the development of medieval art and society., C. He was a key figure in the rejection of physical beauty in art., D. He had no influence on the development of medieval art and society. Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the significance of the story of St. Benedict and the beautiful woman in the context of the transcript? Options: A. It illustrates the importance of physical beauty in art., B. It highlights the dangers of being distracted by physical beauty., C. It has no significance in the context of the transcript., D. It shows the power of physical beauty to inspire spiritual growth. Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I have identified the most similar generated MCQ as:

**Question 5: What was the goal of medieval artists when depicting Jesus and Mary in a way that avoided aesthetically pleasing forms?**

Options: A. To create a sense of realism., B. To inspire sinful thoughts of physical pleasure., C. To focus attention on the virtue they represented., D. To create a sense of drama.

Correct Option: C

Although the question phrasing is not identical, the intent and content of Question 5 align closely with the ground truth MCQ. Both questions address the artist's intention behind depicting Mary in a disproportionate and veiled manner, and both correct options (D in the ground truth MCQ and C in Question 5) convey the idea that the artists aimed to focus attention on the virtue represented by Mary rather than her physical form.

However, another question that closely matches the ground truth MCQ is:

**Question 7: How did the fear of physical beauty influence the depiction of Jesus and Mary in medieval art?**

Options: A. It led to more realistic portrayals., B. It resulted in the use of brighter colors., C. It led to the avoidance of aesthetically pleasing forms., D. It had no impact on the depiction of Jesus and Mary.

Correct Option: C

And also:

**Question 3: According to the transcript, what was the primary concern of early medieval theologians regarding physical beauty?**

Options: A. They believed it was essential for spiritual growth., B. They feared it would distract people from worshiping God., C. They thought it was a necessary aspect of art., D. They saw it as a way to connect with the divine.

Correct Option: B

But among the generated MCQs, **Question 5** is the most similar to the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: **5**

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Transcriber: Andrea McDonough
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar The Oval Office, Inauguration Day, Rose Garden signings, and secret service agents with dark sunglasses and cool wrist radios. For a moment, forget all of it. Toss out everything you know about the President. Now, start over. What would you do if you had to invent the President? That was the question facing the 55 men who got together in secret to draw up the plans for a new American government in the summer of 1787 in Philadelphia, in the same place where the Declaration of Independence had been written eleven years earlier. Declaring independence had been risky business, demanding ferocious courage that put lives and fortunes in jeopardy. But, inventing a new government was no field day either, especially when it's summer and you're in scratchy suits, and the windows are closed because you don't want anybody to hear what you are saying, and the air conditioning doesn't work because it won't be invented for nearly 200 years. And, when you don't agree on things, it gets even hotter. For the framers, the question they argued over most while writing the Constitution and creating three branches of government had to do with the executive department. One man or three to do the job? How long should he serve? What would he really do? Who would pick him? How to get rid of him if he's doing a bad job or he's a crook? And, of course, they all meant him, and he would be a white man. The idea of a woman or an African American, for instance, holding this high office was not a glimmer in their eyes. But the framers knew they needed someone who could take charge, especially in a crisis, like an invasion or a rebellion, or negotiating treaties. Congress was not very good at making such important decisions without debates and delays. But the framers thought America needed a man who was decisive and could act quickly. They called it energy and dispatch. One thing they were dead-set against: there would be no king. They had fought a war against a country with a monarch and were afraid that one man with unchecked powers, in charge of an army, could take over the country. Instead, they settled on a president and laid out his powers in Article 2 of the Constitution. But who would choose him? Not the people, they were too liable to be misled as one framer worried. Not the legislature, that would lead to cabal and factions. Got it: electors, wise, informed men who have time to make a good decision. And if they didn't produce a winner, then the decision would go to one of the other branches of government, the Congress. The House of Representatives would step in and make the choice, which they did in 1801 and 1825. In the long, hot summer of 1787, compromises were made to invent the presidency, like counting slaves as 3/5 of a person, giving the President command of the army but Congress the power to declare war, and unlimited four-year terms. Since then, some of those compromises have been amended and the men in office have sometimes been too strong or too weak. But, if you could start from scratch, how would you redesign the Oval Office?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Where and when was the Constitution written?
Options: A. Philadelphia - 1787, B. Washington D.C. - 1800, C. New York - 1796, D. Boston - 1776
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who drew up the plans for a new American government in the summer of 1787 in Philadelphia? Options: A. The Continental Congress, B. The American people, C. The British monarch, D. The 55 men who met in secret to draw up the plans for a new American government Correct Option: D
Question 2: What was the primary concern of the framers when creating the executive department of the government? Options: A. The role of the judiciary branch, B. The power of the legislative branch, C. The creation of the three branches of government, D. The question of one man or three to do the job, and the powers and responsibilities of the executive Correct Option: D
Question 3: What was the main reason the framers were opposed to having a king in the government? Options: A. They wanted to limit the power of the monarch, B. They were afraid of one man with unchecked powers, C. They wanted to create a more democratic system, D. They were concerned about the cost of a monarchy Correct Option: B
Question 4: According to the transcript, what was the compromise made regarding the counting of slaves in the Constitution? Options: A. Slaves were counted as full persons, B. Slaves were counted as 3/5 of a person, C. Slaves were not counted at all, D. Slaves were given the right to vote Correct Option: B
Question 5: What was the purpose of electors in the selection of the president? Options: A. To give the people a direct say in the election, B. To elect the president through a popular vote, C. To choose the president from among themselves, D. To select a wise and informed leader who would make a good decision, and have time to make a thoughtful choice Correct Option: D
Question 6: If the electors failed to produce a winner, who would make the choice? Options: A. The people, B. The legislature, C. The House of Representatives, D. The Senate Correct Option: C
Question 7: According to the transcript, what were some of the compromises made regarding the powers of the president? Options: A. The president had limited four-year terms, B. The president had the power to declare war, C. The president had the power to command the army, D. All of the above, including unlimited four-year terms and the power to command the army Correct Option: D
Question 8: What was the primary concern of the framers when it came to the selection of the president? Options: A. They wanted to ensure that the president was popular, B. They wanted to ensure that the president was accountable, C. They wanted to ensure that the president was elected by the people, D. They wanted to ensure that the president was decisive and could act quickly, in a crisis or emergency situation Correct Option: D
Question 9: What was the role of the House of Representatives in the selection of the president? Options: A. They had the power to declare war, B. They had the power to command the army, C. They made the choice in 1801 and 1825, when the electors failed to produce a winner, D. They had the power to veto laws Correct Option: C
Question 10: If you could start from scratch, how would you redesign the Oval Office? Options: A. You would keep it the same as it is today, B. You would make it more modern and technologically advanced, C. You would give it more power and authority, D. You would consider factors such as energy and dispatch, accountability, and the ability to make quick decisions in a crisis, while also ensuring that the president is a wise and informed leader Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 1. However, it does not perfectly match the ground truth MCQ, as it asks about who drew up the plans for the new American government, rather than where and when the Constitution was written.

A more suitable match would be a generated MCQ that directly asks about the location and time of the Constitution's writing. Unfortunately, none of the provided generated MCQs perfectly match the ground truth MCQ.

However, if I had to choose the most similar generated MCQ based on the content and context, I would choose Question 1, as it mentions the summer of 1787 in Philadelphia, which is the correct location and time of the Constitution's writing.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 1

But, if you could start from scratch, how would you redesign the Oval Office?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The men who wrote the Constitution are often referred to as the:
Options: A. New England Patriots, B. Founders, C. Framers, D. Federalists
Correct Option: C

Question 1: Who drew up the plans for a new American government in the summer of 1787 in Philadelphia? Options: A. The Continental Congress, B. The American people, C. The British monarch, D. The 55 men who met in secret to draw up the plans for a new American government Correct Option: D
Question 2: What was the primary concern of the framers when creating the executive department of the government? Options: A. The role of the judiciary branch, B. The power of the legislative branch, C. The creation of the three branches of government, D. The question of one man or three to do the job, and the powers and responsibilities of the executive Correct Option: D
Question 3: What was the main reason the framers were opposed to having a king in the government? Options: A. They wanted to limit the power of the monarch, B. They were afraid of one man with unchecked powers, C. They wanted to create a more democratic system, D. They were concerned about the cost of a monarchy Correct Option: B
Question 4: According to the transcript, what was the compromise made regarding the counting of slaves in the Constitution? Options: A. Slaves were counted as full persons, B. Slaves were counted as 3/5 of a person, C. Slaves were not counted at all, D. Slaves were given the right to vote Correct Option: B
Question 5: What was the purpose of electors in the selection of the president? Options: A. To give the people a direct say in the election, B. To elect the president through a popular vote, C. To choose the president from among themselves, D. To select a wise and informed leader who would make a good decision, and have time to make a thoughtful choice Correct Option: D
Question 6: If the electors failed to produce a winner, who would make the choice? Options: A. The people, B. The legislature, C. The House of Representatives, D. The Senate Correct Option: C
Question 7: According to the transcript, what were some of the compromises made regarding the powers of the president? Options: A. The president had limited four-year terms, B. The president had the power to declare war, C. The president had the power to command the army, D. All of the above, including unlimited four-year terms and the power to command the army Correct Option: D
Question 8: What was the primary concern of the framers when it came to the selection of the president? Options: A. They wanted to ensure that the president was popular, B. They wanted to ensure that the president was accountable, C. They wanted to ensure that the president was elected by the people, D. They wanted to ensure that the president was decisive and could act quickly, in a crisis or emergency situation Correct Option: D
Question 9: What was the role of the House of Representatives in the selection of the president? Options: A. They had the power to declare war, B. They had the power to command the army, C. They made the choice in 1801 and 1825, when the electors failed to produce a winner, D. They had the power to veto laws Correct Option: C
Question 10: If you could start from scratch, how would you redesign the Oval Office? Options: A. You would keep it the same as it is today, B. You would make it more modern and technologically advanced, C. You would give it more power and authority, D. You would consider factors such as energy and dispatch, accountability, and the ability to make quick decisions in a crisis, while also ensuring that the president is a wise and informed leader Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Transcriber: Andrea McDonough
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar The Oval Office, Inauguration Day, Rose Garden signings, and secret service agents with dark sunglasses and cool wrist radios. For a moment, forget all of it. Toss out everything you know about the President. Now, start over. What would you do if you had to invent the President? That was the question facing the 55 men who got together in secret to draw up the plans for a new American government in the summer of 1787 in Philadelphia, in the same place where the Declaration of Independence had been written eleven years earlier. Declaring independence had been risky business, demanding ferocious courage that put lives and fortunes in jeopardy. But, inventing a new government was no field day either, especially when it's summer and you're in scratchy suits, and the windows are closed because you don't want anybody to hear what you are saying, and the air conditioning doesn't work because it won't be invented for nearly 200 years. And, when you don't agree on things, it gets even hotter. For the framers, the question they argued over most while writing the Constitution and creating three branches of government had to do with the executive department. One man or three to do the job? How long should he serve? What would he really do? Who would pick him? How to get rid of him if he's doing a bad job or he's a crook? And, of course, they all meant him, and he would be a white man. The idea of a woman or an African American, for instance, holding this high office was not a glimmer in their eyes. But the framers knew they needed someone who could take charge, especially in a crisis, like an invasion or a rebellion, or negotiating treaties. Congress was not very good at making such important decisions without debates and delays. But the framers thought America needed a man who was decisive and could act quickly. They called it energy and dispatch. One thing they were dead-set against: there would be no king. They had fought a war against a country with a monarch and were afraid that one man with unchecked powers, in charge of an army, could take over the country. Instead, they settled on a president and laid out his powers in Article 2 of the Constitution. But who would choose him? Not the people, they were too liable to be misled as one framer worried. Not the legislature, that would lead to cabal and factions. Got it: electors, wise, informed men who have time to make a good decision. And if they didn't produce a winner, then the decision would go to one of the other branches of government, the Congress. The House of Representatives would step in and make the choice, which they did in 1801 and 1825. In the long, hot summer of 1787, compromises were made to invent the presidency, like counting slaves as 3/5 of a person, giving the President command of the army but Congress the power to declare war, and unlimited four-year terms. Since then, some of those compromises have been amended and the men in office have sometimes been too strong or too weak. But, if you could start from scratch, how would you redesign the Oval Office?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The powers of the President are laid out in:
Options: A. Article I of the U.S. Constitution, B. Article II of the U.S. Constitution, C. The Bill of Rights, D. The Ten Commandments
Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. **Transcript**:
so basically we have public leaders public officials who are out of control they're writing bills that are unintelligible and out of these bills are going to come maybe 40,000 pages of regulations total complexity which has a dramatically negative impact on our life if you're a veteran coming back from Iraq or Vietnam you face a blizzard of paperwork to get your benefits if you're trying to get a small business loan you face a blizzard of paperwork what are we going to do about it i define simplicity as a means to achieving clarity transparency and empathy building humanity into communications I've been simplifying things for 30 years I come over the out of the advertising and design business my focus is understanding you people and how you interact with the government to get your benefits how you interact with corporations decide who you're going to do business with and how you view brands so very quickly when President Obama said I don't see why we can't have a one-page plain English consumer credit agreement so I locked myself in a room figured out the content organize the document and wrote it in plain English I've had this checked by the two top consumer credit lawyers in the country this is a real thing now I want one step further and said why do we have to stick with the stodgy lawyers and just have a paper document let's go online so many people might need help in computation working with the Harvard Business School you'll see this example when you talk about minimum payments if you spend sixty two dollars for a meal the longer you take to pay out that loan you see over a period of time using the minimum payment it's 99 dollars and 17 cents how about that you think your bank is going to show that to people but it's going to work it's more effective than just computational aids and what about terms like over the limit perhaps a stealth thing to find it in context tell people what it means when you put it in plain English you almost force the institution to give the people away i default out of that and not put themselves at risk plain english is about changing the content and one of the things I'm most proud of is this agreement for IBM it's a grid its calendar at such-and-such a date IBM F responsibilities you have responsibilities received very favorably by by business and there's some good news to report today each year one in ten taxpayers receive a notice from the IRS there are 200 million letters that go out running through this typical letter that they had I ran it through my simplicity lab it's pretty unintelligible all the parts of the document in red are not intelligible we looked at doing over a thousand letters that cover 70% of the transactions they're in plain English they've been tested in the laboratory when I run it through my lab this heat mapping shows everything is intelligible and the IRS has introduced the program looking at there's one there are a couple of things going on right now that I want to bring to your attention there's a lot of discussion now about consumer financial protection agency how to mandate simplicity we see all this complexity it's incumbent upon us and this organization I believe to make clarity transparency and empathy a national priority there is no way that we should allow government to communicate the way they communicate there is no way we should do business with companies that have agreements with stealth provisions and that aren't intelligible so how are we going to change the world make clarity transparency and simplicity a national priority what does a machine know about itself can it know when it needs to be repaired and when it doesn't in industries like manufacturing and energy they're using predictive analytics to detect signs of trouble helping some companies save millions on maintenance because machines seek help before they're broken and don't when they're not that's what I'm working on I'm an IBM er let's build a smarter planet

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How does Siegel define simplicity?
Options: A. As a means to achieving clarity, B. As a means to achieving transparency, C. As a means to achieving empathy, D. All of the above
Correct Option: D
