that allow us to figure out new things. And so, I have a robot that is creative, it plays piano, is a composer, and if you listen, it plays
"Twinkle, Twinkle Little Star." (Music) So, all of this together, the last thing is interaction. So, you have a robot,
you want it to be your playmate, your teacher, your instructor, you want it to interact. And isn't it so cute? (Laughter) So, interaction is key, it is key to understanding
how to work in our world with us, and so the interaction piece
is very important. It deals with communication,
it deals with understanding, it deals with gaze,
it deals with attention. All of these things together
allow that interaction and our robots to be smart. And so these are just some of the tools that we use in order
to make robots smarter. So, I want to leave you with one thought. So, I'm all for robots and smart robots. I mean, that's what I do, I'd be out of a job
if I didn't believe in that. But yet, where does it end? How far do we push it? How far and how smart
should we make our smart robots? Thank you. (Applause)

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is not an example of mirroring?
Options: A. The ability to see yourself wave in the mirror, B. Watching a baseball pitcher to learn how to throw a ball, C. Repeating the movements of an exercise physiologist to learn how to exercise, D. Reading a book that explains how to do physical tasks
Correct Option: D

**Transcript**:
Transcriber: Andrea McDonough
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar So how many of you have a robot at home? OK, I see about 20, 30 hands. That's actually pretty good. How many of you would want
your own personal robot at home? I know I would! OK, so why doesn't this exist? Why can't I go to the convenience store
or the department store and, you know, go up to the cashier and say,
"Yeah, I want my personal robot"? Well, I'm going to talk to you
about how to make that happen. The thing that we need to do
is to make robots smarter. Now, no one will argue
that we don't have robots. We have rovers that are going to Mars
and are getting science data and expanding our
understanding of the world. We have manufacturing robots that are helping to build our cars
that we drive today. We even have robots
that are helping our military, that are out disposing of bombs so our soldiers can come home safely. So we have all this,
so why don't we have the personal robot? Why don't I have my robot chef?
Because I can't cook. (Laughter) So, here's one of my robots,
this is a simple walking robot, but it is by no means smart. And so, what we need to do is we need to change the definition
of what a robot is. How do we do that? Well, the first step, before we even start designing
and getting our hands dirty, we have to come up with rules,
kind of the laws, rules of conduct. And why is this?
Because if these robots are smart, they might be capable
of more than we want. And so we have to come up with rules. Thou, robot, shall not harm a human. Thou shall obey me, and only me. Thou shall always protect me
at all possible times. So we have to lay the boundaries,
the rules of engagement, before we actually start designing. And then we have to come up with tools. So I believe that the way
to make robots smarter is to mimic people. Now, our brains are complex,
there's a lot going on in there, and so, it'd be hard
to try to open up the brain and actually figure out
how to mimic humans. The best way is to observe,
is to actually watch people do things, and figure out what are they doing,
what are their thoughts, what are their actions,
what are their emotions? And so, part of making robots smarter
is actually trying to mimic humans, mimic how we do things, so maybe they can do it
a little bit better. And so, some of the tools are varied. And so, I'm classically trained
as an electrical engineer. I never thought I'd have to understand
things like child psychology, infant development. So, understanding that the way
infants develop to children, develop to adults,
and how they learn and interact is actually important for robotics. I didn't understand
that I'd actually have to watch tapes of monkeys
interacting and communicating, because they have
a whole social kind of mechanism where they learn from each other, and so that's really good
to make robots smarter. And, of course, neuroscience, I've always been fascinated
with neuroscience, but I never understood
that I had to figure out why do the neurons fire, what about the environment
helps us to learn, and all of those really contribute
to making robots a little bit smarter. And so, some of the things that I do --
and this is just a little snapshot -- one of the things is mirroring. So they say our ability
to look in a mirror and wave and actually recognize
that the person on the other side is us, that self-awareness, is a sign of intelligence, and that allows us
to then look at someone pitch a ball and figure out,
"OK, I know how to pitch a ball, I'm going to mirror their improvement." And so I actually have a robot where we are trying to design
a robot health coach. And so, I have an exercise physiologist showing the robot
how to do some exercises. You know, we want to get strong. And then, the other thing is learning. So, learning is important.
We do this as children, we do this even as adults,
we do this as elder. And yet, one form of learning
is muscle memory. So how many of you play an instrument? OK, so when you start off, for example,
if you think about the violin, you start off and your instructor
might actually come and move your hand a little bit
or maybe move your bow a little bit up. So they actually touch you
in order to give you muscle memory. And that helps you understand
how to do things a little better. And so we actually
have a learning methodology where of course, we're not going
to take the motors and move the legs, and so we have to Nunchuk
to give our robot muscle memory in terms of how to do dance moves. And then, lastly, is creativity. So, you might ask,
"Robots? Creativity? I don't get this. Why does the robot have to be creative?
What about creativity makes them smarter?" Well, creativity and imagination, those are the things
that allow us to create problems when we don't know how to attack it. They allow us to make
something out of nothing. I mean, if you look at the apps
that at out there and the tablets, and the iPads, and the iPhones,
and the Androids -- 20 years ago they didn't exist. So, how is it that we got from something
where there was nothing and expanded? It was our imagination.
It was our creativity. And these are the things
that allow us to figure out new things. And so, I have a robot that is creative, it plays piano, is a composer, and if you listen, it plays
"Twinkle, Twinkle Little Star." (Music) So, all of this together, the last thing is interaction. So, you have a robot,
you want it to be your playmate, your teacher, your instructor, you want it to interact. And isn't it so cute? (Laughter) So, interaction is key, it is key to understanding
how to work in our world with us, and so the interaction piece
is very important. It deals with communication,
it deals with understanding, it deals with gaze,
it deals with attention. All of these things together
allow that interaction and our robots to be smart. And so these are just some of the tools that we use in order
to make robots smarter. So, I want to leave you with one thought. So, I'm all for robots and smart robots. I mean, that's what I do, I'd be out of a job
if I didn't believe in that. But yet, where does it end? How far do we push it? How far and how smart
should we make our smart robots? Thank you. (Applause)

Options: A. Creative kinesthetics, B. Muscle memory, C. Lather, rinse, repeat learning, D. Pulse reactive method

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 20, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Transcriber: Andrea McDonough
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar The development and spread of railroads across the United States brought a wave of changes to American life. During the railroad boom, thousands of jobs were created, new towns were born, trade increased, transportation was faster, and the overall landscape of the nation transformed. But, perhaps the most interesting change of all is the least known: the establishment of standard time. Today, we know if it is 6:28 a.m. in Los Angeles, it is 9:28 a.m. in New York, 2:28 p.m. in London, 5:28 p.m. in Moscow, and 10:28 p.m in Tokyo. No matter where you are, the minute and second are the exact same. But, before the railroads, there was no need for a national or global clock, and each town kept its own local time. So when it was 12 noon in Chicago, it was 12:07 p.m. in Indianapolis, 11:50 a.m. in St. Louis, and 11:27 a.m. in Omaha. This worked just fine when the only modes of travel were horses or steamboats, but it became incredibly problematic when railroads came along. How can you keep a train schedule when each town has its own time? And how do you prevent collisions or accidents on the tracks if train conductors are using different clocks? It doesn't really make sense to leave a station at 12:14 p.m., travel for 22 minutes, and arrive at 12:31 p.m. In order to eliminate that confusion, the railroads of the United States and Canada instituted standard time zones on November 18, 1883 at noon. It allowed the railroad companies to operate more effectively and reduce deadly accidents. The American public, however, was not so quick to embrace this new change, as many cities continued to use their own local time. Resistance was so strong that, in some towns, clocks would show both the local time and the railway time. Imagine this conversation: "Pardon me, sir. Do you have the time?" "Why yes, which do you need? It's 12:13 local time and 12:16 railway time." Ultimately, the logic of keeping a standard time prevailed, and the United States government made time zones a matter of law with the Standard Time Act of March 19, 1918. Since then, there have been numerous changes to the time zones, but the concept of standard time has remained. But, the United States was actually not the first to develop standard time. The first company to implement the use of standard time was the Great Western Railway in 1840 in Britain, and by 1847, most British railways were using Greenwich Mean Time, or G.M.T. The British government made it official on August 2, 1880 with the Statutes, or Definition of Time, Act. But, while Britain may have been the first to establish standard time, it is Asia and the islands of the South Pacific that enjoyed the first hour of each new day. The International Date Line passes through the Pacific Ocean on the opposite side of the Earth from the Prime Meridian in Greenwich where, thanks to trains, standard time was first used. Trains have evolved over the years and remain a prominent form of transportation and trade throughout the world. And, from the New York City subways to the freight trains traveling across the Great Plains, to the trolleys in San Francisco, they all know exactly what time it is. And, thanks to them, we do too!

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: According to Heuisler, the most interesting change that occurred during the railroad boom is ____________.
Options: A. Cross country transportation, B. A increase in urbanization, C. The establishment of standard time, D. A similar boom in employment
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the primary impact of the railroad boom on American life? Options: A. The creation of new jobs and the establishment of standard time, B. The transformation of the nation's landscape and the increase in trade, C. The faster transportation and the birth of new towns, D. The decline of the railroad industry and the loss of jobs Correct Option: B
Question 2: What was the main problem that the railroads faced before the establishment of standard time? Options: A. The lack of coordination between train schedules, B. The use of different clocks in each town, leading to confusion and potential collisions on the tracks, C. The difficulty in preventing accidents on the tracks, D. The high cost of maintaining the railroads Correct Option: B
Question 3: How did the American public initially react to the introduction of standard time? Options: A. They enthusiastically adopted it, B. They were neutral about it, C. They resisted it and continued to use their local time, D. They were unaware of it Correct Option: C
Question 4: What would be the consequence of not having a standard time zone in a region with multiple railroads? Options: A. Reduced accidents and increased efficiency, B. Increased coordination between train schedules, C. Confusion and potential collisions on the tracks, as well as difficulties in keeping train schedules, D. No impact on the railroads Correct Option: C
Question 5: What was the first company to implement the use of standard time? Options: A. The Great Western Railway in Britain, B. The American railroads in the United States, C. The British government, D. The International Date Line Correct Option: A
Question 6: What is the significance of the International Date Line in relation to standard time? Options: A. It marks the beginning of a new day, with Asia and the islands of the South Pacific enjoying the first hour of each new day, B. It separates the East and West hemispheres, C. It has no relation to standard time, D. It is a geographical feature with no significance Correct Option: A
Question 7: What was the main reason for the British government to make standard time official in 1880? Options: A. To increase trade and commerce, B. To reduce accidents on the tracks, C. To simplify the use of clocks and watches, D. To make it a matter of law Correct Option: D
Question 8: What was the name of the act that made time zones a matter of law in the United States? Options: A. The Standard Time Act, B. The Railroad Act, C. The Time Zone Act, D. The Clock Act Correct Option: A
Question 9: What is the significance of the Prime Meridian in Greenwich in relation to standard time? Options: A. It marks the beginning of a new day, B. It separates the East and West hemispheres, C. It is the reference point for standard time, with trains using standard time since its implementation, D. It has no relation to standard time Correct Option: C
Question 10: How has the concept of standard time evolved over time? Options: A. It has remained the same, B. It has become more complex, C. It has become more simplified, with the introduction of time zones and the widespread adoption of standard time, D. It has been replaced by a new concept Correct Option: C
Question 11: What was the date when the railroads in the United States and Canada instituted standard time zones? Options: A. November 18, 1883, B. March 19, 1918, C. August 2, 1880, D. December 31, 1899 Correct Option: A
Question 12: What was the name of the act passed by the British government in 1880 that made standard time official? Options: A. The Statutes, or Definition of Time, Act, B. The Standard Time Act, C. The Time Zone Act, D. The Clock Act Correct Option: A
Question 13: What was the initial reaction of some towns in the United States to the introduction of standard time? Options: A. They enthusiastically adopted it, B. They were neutral about it, C. They continued to use both local and railway time, D. They were unaware of it Correct Option: C
Question 14: What was the significance of the Standard Time Act of 1918 in the United States? Options: A. It made time zones a matter of law, B. It increased trade and commerce, C. It simplified the use of clocks and watches, D. It had no relation to standard time Correct Option: A
Question 15: What is the significance of the International Date Line in relation to the first hour of each new day? Options: A. It marks the beginning of a new day in the West, B. It marks the beginning of a new day in the East, C. It marks the beginning of a new day in Asia and the islands of the South Pacific, D. It has no relation to the first hour of each new day Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 20, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Transcriber: Andrea McDonough
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar The development and spread of railroads across the United States brought a wave of changes to American life. During the railroad boom, thousands of jobs were created, new towns were born, trade increased, transportation was faster, and the overall landscape of the nation transformed. But, perhaps the most interesting change of all is the least known: the establishment of standard time. Today, we know if it is 6:28 a.m. in Los Angeles, it is 9:28 a.m. in New York, 2:28 p.m. in London, 5:28 p.m. in Moscow, and 10:28 p.m in Tokyo. No matter where you are, the minute and second are the exact same. But, before the railroads, there was no need for a national or global clock, and each town kept its own local time. So when it was 12 noon in Chicago, it was 12:07 p.m. in Indianapolis, 11:50 a.m. in St. Louis, and 11:27 a.m. in Omaha. This worked just fine when the only modes of travel were horses or steamboats, but it became incredibly problematic when railroads came along. How can you keep a train schedule when each town has its own time? And how do you prevent collisions or accidents on the tracks if train conductors are using different clocks? It doesn't really make sense to leave a station at 12:14 p.m., travel for 22 minutes, and arrive at 12:31 p.m. In order to eliminate that confusion, the railroads of the United States and Canada instituted standard time zones on November 18, 1883 at noon. It allowed the railroad companies to operate more effectively and reduce deadly accidents. The American public, however, was not so quick to embrace this new change, as many cities continued to use their own local time. Resistance was so strong that, in some towns, clocks would show both the local time and the railway time. Imagine this conversation: "Pardon me, sir. Do you have the time?" "Why yes, which do you need? It's 12:13 local time and 12:16 railway time." Ultimately, the logic of keeping a standard time prevailed, and the United States government made time zones a matter of law with the Standard Time Act of March 19, 1918. Since then, there have been numerous changes to the time zones, but the concept of standard time has remained. But, the United States was actually not the first to develop standard time. The first company to implement the use of standard time was the Great Western Railway in 1840 in Britain, and by 1847, most British railways were using Greenwich Mean Time, or G.M.T. The British government made it official on August 2, 1880 with the Statutes, or Definition of Time, Act. But, while Britain may have been the first to establish standard time, it is Asia and the islands of the South Pacific that enjoyed the first hour of each new day. The International Date Line passes through the Pacific Ocean on the opposite side of the Earth from the Prime Meridian in Greenwich where, thanks to trains, standard time was first used. Trains have evolved over the years and remain a prominent form of transportation and trade throughout the world. And, from the New York City subways to the freight trains traveling across the Great Plains, to the trolleys in San Francisco, they all know exactly what time it is. And, thanks to them, we do too!

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What day were standard time zones implemented?
Options: A. November 24, 1983 (Thanksgiving Day), B. November 18, 1883, C. January 1, 1870 (New Year's Day), D. February 3, 1884
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the primary impact of the railroad boom on American life? Options: A. The creation of new jobs and the establishment of standard time, B. The transformation of the nation's landscape and the increase in trade, C. The faster transportation and the birth of new towns, D. The decline of the railroad industry and the loss of jobs Correct Option: B
Question 2: What was the main problem that the railroads faced before the establishment of standard time? Options: A. The lack of coordination between train schedules, B. The use of different clocks in each town, leading to confusion and potential collisions on the tracks, C. The difficulty in preventing accidents on the tracks, D. The high cost of maintaining the railroads Correct Option: B
Question 3: How did the American public initially react to the introduction of standard time? Options: A. They enthusiastically adopted it, B. They were neutral about it, C. They resisted it and continued to use their local time, D. They were unaware of it Correct Option: C
Question 4: What would be the consequence of not having a standard time zone in a region with multiple railroads? Options: A. Reduced accidents and increased efficiency, B. Increased coordination between train schedules, C. Confusion and potential collisions on the tracks, as well as difficulties in keeping train schedules, D. No impact on the railroads Correct Option: C
Question 5: What was the first company to implement the use of standard time? Options: A. The Great Western Railway in Britain, B. The American railroads in the United States, C. The British government, D. The International Date Line Correct Option: A
Question 6: What is the significance of the International Date Line in relation to standard time? Options: A. It marks the beginning of a new day, with Asia and the islands of the South Pacific enjoying the first hour of each new day, B. It separates the East and West hemispheres, C. It has no relation to standard time, D. It is a geographical feature with no significance Correct Option: A
Question 7: What was the main reason for the British government to make standard time official in 1880? Options: A. To increase trade and commerce, B. To reduce accidents on the tracks, C. To simplify the use of clocks and watches, D. To make it a matter of law Correct Option: D
Question 8: What was the name of the act that made time zones a matter of law in the United States? Options: A. The Standard Time Act, B. The Railroad Act, C. The Time Zone Act, D. The Clock Act Correct Option: A
Question 9: What is the significance of the Prime Meridian in Greenwich in relation to standard time? Options: A. It marks the beginning of a new day, B. It separates the East and West hemispheres, C. It is the reference point for standard time, with trains using standard time since its implementation, D. It has no relation to standard time Correct Option: C
Question 10: How has the concept of standard time evolved over time? Options: A. It has remained the same, B. It has become more complex, C. It has become more simplified, with the introduction of time zones and the widespread adoption of standard time, D. It has been replaced by a new concept Correct Option: C
Question 11: What was the date when the railroads in the United States and Canada instituted standard time zones? Options: A. November 18, 1883, B. March 19, 1918, C. August 2, 1880, D. December 31, 1899 Correct Option: A
Question 12: What was the name of the act passed by the British government in 1880 that made standard time official? Options: A. The Statutes, or Definition of Time, Act, B. The Standard Time Act, C. The Time Zone Act, D. The Clock Act Correct Option: A
Question 13: What was the initial reaction of some towns in the United States to the introduction of standard time? Options: A. They enthusiastically adopted it, B. They were neutral about it, C. They continued to use both local and railway time, D. They were unaware of it Correct Option: C
Question 14: What was the significance of the Standard Time Act of 1918 in the United States? Options: A. It made time zones a matter of law, B. It increased trade and commerce, C. It simplified the use of clocks and watches, D. It had no relation to standard time Correct Option: A
Question 15: What is the significance of the International Date Line in relation to the first hour of each new day? Options: A. It marks the beginning of a new day in the West, B. It marks the beginning of a new day in the East, C. It marks the beginning of a new day in Asia and the islands of the South Pacific, D. It has no relation to the first hour of each new day Correct Option: C

**Transcript**:
Transcriber: Andrea McDonough
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar The development and spread of railroads across the United States brought a wave of changes to American life. During the railroad boom, thousands of jobs were created, new towns were born, trade increased, transportation was faster, and the overall landscape of the nation transformed. But, perhaps the most interesting change of all is the least known: the establishment of standard time. Today, we know if it is 6:28 a.m. in Los Angeles, it is 9:28 a.m. in New York, 2:28 p.m. in London, 5:28 p.m. in Moscow, and 10:28 p.m in Tokyo. No matter where you are, the minute and second are the exact same. But, before the railroads, there was no need for a national or global clock, and each town kept its own local time. So when it was 12 noon in Chicago, it was 12:07 p.m. in Indianapolis, 11:50 a.m. in St. Louis, and 11:27 a.m. in Omaha. This worked just fine when the only modes of travel were horses or steamboats, but it became incredibly problematic when railroads came along. How can you keep a train schedule when each town has its own time? And how do you prevent collisions or accidents on the tracks if train conductors are using different clocks? It doesn't really make sense to leave a station at 12:14 p.m., travel for 22 minutes, and arrive at 12:31 p.m. In order to eliminate that confusion, the railroads of the United States and Canada instituted standard time zones on November 18, 1883 at noon. It allowed the railroad companies to operate more effectively and reduce deadly accidents. The American public, however, was not so quick to embrace this new change, as many cities continued to use their own local time. Resistance was so strong that, in some towns, clocks would show both the local time and the railway time. Imagine this conversation: "Pardon me, sir. Do you have the time?" "Why yes, which do you need? It's 12:13 local time and 12:16 railway time." Ultimately, the logic of keeping a standard time prevailed, and the United States government made time zones a matter of law with the Standard Time Act of March 19, 1918. Since then, there have been numerous changes to the time zones, but the concept of standard time has remained. But, the United States was actually not the first to develop standard time. The first company to implement the use of standard time was the Great Western Railway in 1840 in Britain, and by 1847, most British railways were using Greenwich Mean Time, or G.M.T. The British government made it official on August 2, 1880 with the Statutes, or Definition of Time, Act. But, while Britain may have been the first to establish standard time, it is Asia and the islands of the South Pacific that enjoyed the first hour of each new day. The International Date Line passes through the Pacific Ocean on the opposite side of the Earth from the Prime Meridian in Greenwich where, thanks to trains, standard time was first used. Trains have evolved over the years and remain a prominent form of transportation and trade throughout the world. And, from the New York City subways to the freight trains traveling across the Great Plains, to the trolleys in San Francisco, they all know exactly what time it is. And, thanks to them, we do too!

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Ultimately, the logic of standard time zones prevailed, and the US government made time zones a matter of law with ____________.
Options: A. The Global Clock Law of 1899, B. The Standard Time Act of 1918, C. The Time Zone Law of 1920, D. The Universal Time Act of 1884
Correct Option: B

Transcriber: Andrea McDonough
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar The development and spread of railroads across the United States brought a wave of changes to American life. Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is:

**Question 5: What was the first company to implement the use of standard time? Options: A. The Great Western Railway in Britain, B. The American railroads in the United States, C. The British government, D. The International Date Line Correct Option: A**

This question has the same intent, options, and content as the ground truth MCQ, with the correct option being the Great Western Railway in Britain.

The index of the most similar generated MCQ is: **5**

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 20, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Transcriber: Andrea McDonough
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar The development and spread of railroads across the United States brought a wave of changes to American life. During the railroad boom, thousands of jobs were created, new towns were born, trade increased, transportation was faster, and the overall landscape of the nation transformed. But, perhaps the most interesting change of all is the least known: the establishment of standard time. Today, we know if it is 6:28 a.m. in Los Angeles, it is 9:28 a.m. in New York, 2:28 p.m. in London, 5:28 p.m. in Moscow, and 10:28 p.m in Tokyo. No matter where you are, the minute and second are the exact same. But, before the railroads, there was no need for a national or global clock, and each town kept its own local time. So when it was 12 noon in Chicago, it was 12:07 p.m. in Indianapolis, 11:50 a.m. in St. Louis, and 11:27 a.m. in Omaha. This worked just fine when the only modes of travel were horses or steamboats, but it became incredibly problematic when railroads came along. How can you keep a train schedule when each town has its own time? And how do you prevent collisions or accidents on the tracks if train conductors are using different clocks? It doesn't really make sense to leave a station at 12:14 p.m., travel for 22 minutes, and arrive at 12:31 p.m. In order to eliminate that confusion, the railroads of the United States and Canada instituted standard time zones on November 18, 1883 at noon. It allowed the railroad companies to operate more effectively and reduce deadly accidents. The American public, however, was not so quick to embrace this new change, as many cities continued to use their own local time. Resistance was so strong that, in some towns, clocks would show both the local time and the railway time. Imagine this conversation: "Pardon me, sir. Do you have the time?" "Why yes, which do you need? It's 12:13 local time and 12:16 railway time." Ultimately, the logic of keeping a standard time prevailed, and the United States government made time zones a matter of law with the Standard Time Act of March 19, 1918. Since then, there have been numerous changes to the time zones, but the concept of standard time has remained. But, the United States was actually not the first to develop standard time. The first company to implement the use of standard time was the Great Western Railway in 1840 in Britain, and by 1847, most British railways were using Greenwich Mean Time, or G.M.T. The British government made it official on August 2, 1880 with the Statutes, or Definition of Time, Act. But, while Britain may have been the first to establish standard time, it is Asia and the islands of the South Pacific that enjoyed the first hour of each new day. The International Date Line passes through the Pacific Ocean on the opposite side of the Earth from the Prime Meridian in Greenwich where, thanks to trains, standard time was first used. Trains have evolved over the years and remain a prominent form of transportation and trade throughout the world. And, from the New York City subways to the freight trains traveling across the Great Plains, to the trolleys in San Francisco, they all know exactly what time it is. And, thanks to them, we do too!

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What area of the world enjoys the first hour of the day?
Options: A. Asia and the South Pacific, B. Austrailia, C. Canada and Alaska, D. Central and South America
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the primary impact of the railroad boom on American life? Options: A. The creation of new jobs and the establishment of standard time, B. The transformation of the nation's landscape and the increase in trade, C. The faster transportation and the birth of new towns, D. The decline of the railroad industry and the loss of jobs Correct Option: B
Question 2: What was the main problem that the railroads faced before the establishment of standard time? Options: A. The lack of coordination between train schedules, B. The use of different clocks in each town, leading to confusion and potential collisions on the tracks, C. The difficulty in preventing accidents on the tracks, D. The high cost of maintaining the railroads Correct Option: B
Question 3: How did the American public initially react to the introduction of standard time? Options: A. They enthusiastically adopted it, B. They were neutral about it, C. They resisted it and continued to use their local time, D. They were unaware of it Correct Option: C
Question 4: What would be the consequence of not having a standard time zone in a region with multiple railroads? Options: A. Reduced accidents and increased efficiency, B. Increased coordination between train schedules, C. Confusion and potential collisions on the tracks, as well as difficulties in keeping train schedules, D. No impact on the railroads Correct Option: C
Question 5: What was the first company to implement the use of standard time? Options: A. The Great Western Railway in Britain, B. The American railroads in the United States, C. The British government, D. The International Date Line Correct Option: A
Question 6: What is the significance of the International Date Line in relation to standard time? Options: A. It marks the beginning of a new day, with Asia and the islands of the South Pacific enjoying the first hour of each new day, B. It separates the East and West hemispheres, C. It has no relation to standard time, D. It is a geographical feature with no significance Correct Option: A
Question 7: What was the main reason for the British government to make standard time official in 1880? Options: A. To increase trade and commerce, B. To reduce accidents on the tracks, C. To simplify the use of clocks and watches, D. To make it a matter of law Correct Option: D
Question 8: What was the name of the act that made time zones a matter of law in the United States? Options: A. The Standard Time Act, B. The Railroad Act, C. The Time Zone Act, D. The Clock Act Correct Option: A
Question 9: What is the significance of the Prime Meridian in Greenwich in relation to standard time? Options: A. It marks the beginning of a new day, B. It separates the East and West hemispheres, C. It is the reference point for standard time, with trains using standard time since its implementation, D. It has no relation to standard time Correct Option: C
Question 10: How has the concept of standard time evolved over time? Options: A. It has remained the same, B. It has become more complex, C. It has become more simplified, with the introduction of time zones and the widespread adoption of standard time, D. It has been replaced by a new concept Correct Option: C
Question 11: What was the date when the railroads in the United States and Canada instituted standard time zones? Options: A. November 18, 1883, B. March 19, 1918, C. August 2, 1880, D. December 31, 1899 Correct Option: A
Question 12: What was the name of the act passed by the British government in 1880 that made standard time official? Options: A. The Statutes, or Definition of Time, Act, B. The Standard Time Act, C. The Time Zone Act, D. The Clock Act Correct Option: A
Question 13: What was the initial reaction of some towns in the United States to the introduction of standard time? Options: A. They enthusiastically adopted it, B. They were neutral about it, C. They continued to use both local and railway time, D. They were unaware of it Correct Option: C
Question 14: What was the significance of the Standard Time Act of 1918 in the United States? Options: A. It made time zones a matter of law, B. It increased trade and commerce, C. It simplified the use of clocks and watches, D. It had no relation to standard time Correct Option: A
Question 15: What is the significance of the International Date Line in relation to the first hour of each new day? Options: A. It marks the beginning of a new day in the West, B. It marks the beginning of a new day in the East, C. It marks the beginning of a new day in Asia and the islands of the South Pacific, D. It has no relation to the first hour of each new day Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 21, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Transcriber: Andrea McDonough
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar How come some insects are able to walk on the surface of a pond, but you quickly sink to the bottom when you try to walk on water? And why do lakes freeze from the top down in winter? In a word, the answer to all these questions is polarity. Water is a simple molecule made up of one oxygen atom and two hydrogen atoms, but it is essential to life. In fact, water makes up approximately 60% of the adult human being's body weight. The polarity within those water molecules gives this common substance the properties that make it unique and life-sustaining. Polarity refers to the unequal sharing of electrons within a molecule. For water, the bonding between the oxygen atom and two hydrogen atoms within a single water molecule is like a tug-of-war between a big, strong football player and a cute little toddler. Oxygen is a larger atom, with more protons in its nucleus than hydrogen. These positive charges are like a person's physical strength. They're able to attract the negatively charged electrons in the bond, just like a strong individual is able to overpower a weaker individual in a tug of war. So, oxygen is able to attract more than its fair share of electrons. Because hydrogen is smaller and has less strength, or fewer protons, it loses the tug of war and attracts fewer than its fair share of electrons. So, the oxygen in water behaves as though it's negative, and the hydrogens behave as though they're positive. The bonds within a single water molecule are called polar covalent bonds. Covalent means that the electrons are shared. But, as we just learned, polar means that these electrons are not shared equally. In water, the oxygen acts negative and the hydrogens act positive. Since negative and positive attract, that oxygen is attracted to the hydrogen atoms in neighboring water molecules. A special type of bond forms between water molecules, known as a hydrogen bond. Hydrogen bonds don't just happen in water either. They can form between a water molecule and different substances that are polar or ionic. Water's ability to stick to itself is called cohesion, while water's ability to stick to other substances is called adhesion. Now, think back to the initial questions. First, why are some insects able to walk on water? Surface tension due to hydrogen bonding creates a thin film on the surface of water that gives enough resistance for super-light insects to walk on. You can't walk on it because the hydrogen bonds aren't strong enough to hold you up. Why does ice float on top of liquid water? For most other substances, the solid state is more dense than the liquid state, but that is not the case for water! Hydrogen bonds keep water molecules farther apart in frozen water than in liquid water. The farther apart the molecules are, the less dense that solid is. So ice is about 9% less dense than water, which means it floats on the top. That's why lakes freeze from the top down and aquatic life is able to survive through a cold winter every year. It is the polarity of the water molecule and the resulting hydrogen bonding that account for water's unique properties. So, the reason that water is so special, from inside your cells to the world's oceans, is simply because it is a polar molecule.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Polarity refers to the _______________ in a molecule.
Options: A. Unequal sharing of protons, B. Unequal sharing of electrons, C. Equal sharing of protons, D. Equal sharing of electrons
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What percentage of the adult human body weight is made up of water? Options: A. 40%, B. 50%, C. 60%, D. 70% Correct Option: C
Question 2: What type of bond forms between water molecules due to their polarity? Options: A. Ionic bond, B. Covalent bond, C. Hydrogen bond, D. Polar bond Correct Option: C
Question 3: Why are some insects able to walk on the surface of a pond? Options: A. Due to their heavy weight, B. Due to the surface tension of the water, C. Due to their ability to hold their breath, D. Due to the water's high temperature Correct Option: B
Question 4: What happens to the density of water when it freezes? Options: A. It becomes more dense, B. It becomes less dense, C. It remains the same, D. It becomes even less dense Correct Option: B
Question 5: Why does ice float on top of liquid water in lakes? Options: A. Because it is more dense than water, B. Because it is less dense than water, C. Because it is the same density as water, D. Because it is affected by the surrounding temperature Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the primary reason why water is essential for life? Options: A. Its ability to conduct electricity, B. Its ability to hold a high temperature, C. Its polarity and resulting hydrogen bonding, D. Its ability to dissolve other substances Correct Option: C
Question 7: What would happen if water molecules were not polar? Options: A. They would still be able to form hydrogen bonds, B. They would not be able to form hydrogen bonds, C. They would become more dense, D. They would become less dense Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the difference between cohesion and adhesion in water? Options: A. Cohesion refers to water's ability to stick to itself, while adhesion refers to its ability to stick to other substances, B. Cohesion refers to water's ability to stick to other substances, while adhesion refers to its ability to stick to itself, C. Cohesion refers to water's ability to conduct electricity, while adhesion refers to its ability to hold a high temperature, D. Cohesion refers to water's ability to dissolve other substances, while adhesion refers to its ability to conduct electricity Correct Option: A
Question 9: Why is it essential for lakes to freeze from the top down in winter? Options: A. So that aquatic life can survive through the cold winter, B. So that the water can become more dense, C. So that the water can hold a high temperature, D. So that the water can conduct electricity Correct Option: A
Question 10: What is the primary property of water that makes it unique and life-sustaining? Options: A. Its ability to conduct electricity, B. Its ability to hold a high temperature, C. Its polarity and resulting hydrogen bonding, D. Its ability to dissolve other substances Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is not explicitly listed. However, based on the question intent, options, and content, the closest match would be a question that asks about the definition of polarity. 

Among the provided generated MCQs, none directly ask about the definition of polarity. However, Question 6 and Question 10 mention polarity as part of the correct option. But they do not directly ask for the definition of polarity.

If I had to choose the closest match from the provided generated MCQs, I would say that Question 6 or Question 10 could be considered as a possible match, but they are not exact matches.

However, I must emphasize that none of the provided generated MCQs directly ask about the definition of polarity, which is the intent of the ground truth MCQ.

The oxygen atom acts as if it has a negative charge while the hydrogen atoms act as if they have a positive charge.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 21, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. **Transcript**:
Transcriber: Andrea McDonough
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar How come some insects are able to walk on the surface of a pond, but you quickly sink to the bottom when you try to walk on water? And why do lakes freeze from the top down in winter? In a word, the answer to all these questions is polarity. So, oxygen is able to attract more than its fair share of electrons. Because hydrogen is smaller and has less strength, or fewer protons, it loses the tug of war and attracts fewer than its fair share of electrons. So, the oxygen in water behaves as though it's negative, and the hydrogens behave as though they're positive. The bonds within a single water molecule are called polar covalent bonds. Covalent means that the electrons are shared. But, as we just learned, polar means that these electrons are not shared equally. In water, the oxygen acts negative and the hydrogens act positive. Since negative and positive attract, that oxygen is attracted to the hydrogen atoms in neighboring water molecules. A special type of bond forms between water molecules, known as a hydrogen bond. Hydrogen bonds don't just happen in water either. They can form between a water molecule and different substances that are polar or ionic. Water's ability to stick to itself is called cohesion, while water's ability to stick to other substances is called adhesion. Now, think back to the initial questions. First, why are some insects able to walk on water? Surface tension due to hydrogen bonding creates a thin film on the surface of water that gives enough resistance for super-light insects to walk on. You can't walk on it because the hydrogen bonds aren't strong enough to hold you up. Why does ice float on top of liquid water? For most other substances, the solid state is more dense than the liquid state, but that is not the case for water! Hydrogen bonds keep water molecules farther apart in frozen water than in liquid water. The farther apart the molecules are, the less dense that solid is. So ice is about 9% less dense than water, which means it floats on the top. That's why lakes freeze from the top down and aquatic life is able to survive through a cold winter every year. It is the polarity of the water molecule and the resulting hydrogen bonding that account for water's unique properties. So, the reason that water is so special, from inside your cells to the world's oceans, is simply because it is a polar molecule.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The property of water that refers to its ability to stick to itself is called _____________.
Options: A. Capillarity, B. Adhesion, C. Cohesion, D. High specific heat
Correct Option: C

**Transcript**:
Transcriber: Andrea McDonough
Reviewer: Bedirhan Cinar How come some insects are able to walk on the surface of a pond, but you quickly sink to the bottom when you try to walk on water? And why do lakes freeze from the top down in winter? In a word, the answer to all these questions is polarity. Water is a simple molecule made up of one oxygen atom and two hydrogen atoms, but it is essential to life. In fact, water makes up approximately 60% of the adult human being's body weight. The polarity within those water molecules gives this common substance the properties that make it unique and life-sustaining. Polarity refers to the unequal sharing of electrons within a molecule. For water, the bonding between the oxygen atom and two hydrogen atoms within a single water molecule is like a tug-of-war between a big, strong football player and a cute little toddler. Oxygen is a larger atom, with more protons in its nucleus than hydrogen. These positive charges are like a person's physical strength. They're able to attract the negatively charged electrons in the bond, just like a strong individual is able to overpower a weaker individual in a tug of war. So, oxygen is able to attract more than its fair share of electrons. Because hydrogen is smaller and has less strength, or fewer protons, it loses the tug of war and attracts fewer than its fair share of electrons. So, the oxygen in water behaves as though it's negative, and the hydrogens behave as though they're positive. The bonds within a single water molecule are called polar covalent bonds. Covalent means that the electrons are shared. But, as we just learned, polar means that these electrons are not shared equally. In water, the oxygen acts negative and the hydrogens act positive. Since negative and positive attract, that oxygen is attracted to the hydrogen atoms in neighboring water molecules. A special type of bond forms between water molecules, known as a hydrogen bond. Hydrogen bonds don't just happen in water either. They can form between a water molecule and different substances that are polar or ionic. Water's ability to stick to itself is called cohesion, while water's ability to stick to other substances is called adhesion. Now, think back to the initial questions. First, why are some insects able to walk on water? Surface tension due to hydrogen bonding creates a thin film on the surface of water that gives enough resistance for super-light insects to walk on. You can't walk on it because the hydrogen bonds aren't strong enough to hold you up. Why does ice float on top of liquid water? For most other substances, the solid state is more dense than the liquid state, but that is not the case for water! Hydrogen bonds keep water molecules farther apart in frozen water than in liquid water. The farther apart the molecules are, the less dense that solid is. So ice is about 9% less dense than water, which means it floats on the top. That's why lakes freeze from the top down and aquatic life is able to survive through a cold winter every year. It is the polarity of the water molecule and the resulting hydrogen bonding that account for water's unique properties. So, the reason that water is so special, from inside your cells to the world's oceans, is simply because it is a polar molecule.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:

Options: A. The amount of hydrogen bonding decreases as temperature increases., B. The amount of hydrogen bonding increases as temperature increases., C. The amount of hydrogen bonding remains constant as temperature increases., D. There is no relationship between the amount of hydrogen bonding and the temperature.
Correct Option: A

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 1. 

Ground Truth MCQ: What triggered Dan Ariely's interest in irrational behavior?
Generated MCQ 1: What inspired the speaker's interest in irrational behavior?

Both questions have the same intent, which is to understand what sparked the speaker's interest in irrational behavior. The options in the generated MCQ are not identical to the ground truth MCQ, but they convey the same idea. The correct option in both cases refers to a personal experience that triggered the speaker's interest in irrational behavior. 

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 1.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What experiment did Ariely carry out because of his interest in how to remove bandages from burn patients?
Options: A. He burned mice, B. He went sky-diving, C. He gathered information from nurses in burn units at hospitals, D. He tested people's degrees of pain
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What inspired the speaker's interest in irrational behavior? Options: A. A personal experience with a hospital nurse, B. A study on economics and finance, C. A research project on behavioral psychology, D. A lecture on sociology and anthropology Correct Option: A
Question 2: What was the speaker's hypothesis about the nurses' approach to removing bandages? Options: A. That they were right in using a quick and intense method, B. That they were wrong and a slower approach would be more effective, C. That the method didn't matter as long as the nurse was experienced, D. That the patient's pain was irrelevant to the decision Correct Option: B
Question 3: What did the speaker's experiment on cheating reveal about human behavior? Options: A. That people are generally honest and trustworthy, B. That people cheat only when they think they can get away with it, C. That people cheat more when they are given a personal fudge factor, D. That people cheat just a little bit, and are influenced by social norms and distance from money Correct Option: D
Question 4: What is the concept of a "personal fudge factor" in the context of cheating? Options: A. A level of cheating that people can tolerate without feeling guilty, B. A factor that increases the likelihood of cheating, C. A factor that decreases the likelihood of cheating, D. A factor that has no effect on cheating behavior Correct Option: A
Question 5: What did the speaker's experiment on the Ten Commandments reveal about human behavior? Options: A. That people who remember more of the commandments are more likely to cheat, B. That people who remember more of the commandments are less likely to cheat, C. That there is no correlation between remembering the commandments and cheating behavior, D. That the experiment had no effect on cheating behavior Correct Option: B
Question 6: What did the speaker's experiment on cheating reveal about human behavior in the context of social norms? Options: A. That people are more likely to cheat when they see others cheating around them, B. That people are less likely to cheat when they see others cheating around them, C. That people cheat equally when they see others cheating around them, D. That the experiment had no effect on cheating behavior Correct Option: A
Question 7: What did the speaker learn from his experience with the nurses and his own intuitions? Options: A. That our intuitions are always right and should not be questioned, B. That our intuitions are often wrong and should be tested, C. That our intuitions are irrelevant to decision-making, D. That our intuitions are the only way to make decisions Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the concept of predictive analytics in the context of machine maintenance? Options: A. A method of predicting when a machine will break down, B. A method of detecting signs of trouble in a machine, C. A method of optimizing machine performance, D. A method of reducing maintenance costs Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the speaker's goal in building a smarter planet? Options: A. To reduce energy consumption, B. To improve machine maintenance, C. To create a more efficient and sustainable planet, D. To increase profit margins Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the speaker's profession? Options: A. Economist, B. Psychologist, C. IBM researcher, D. Sociologist Correct Option: C
Question 11: What did the speaker's experiment on the Carnegie Mellon students reveal about human behavior? Options: A. That people cheat more when they see others cheating around them, B. That people cheat less when they see others cheating around them, C. That people cheat equally when they see others cheating around them, D. That the experiment had no effect on cheating behavior Correct Option: A
Question 12: What did the speaker's experiment on stock options reveal about human behavior in the context of the stock market? Options: A. That people are less likely to cheat when they are given a large amount of money, B. That people are more likely to cheat when they are given a large amount of money, C. That people are less likely to cheat when they see others cheating around them, D. That people are more likely to cheat when they see others cheating around them Correct Option: D
Question 13: What did the speaker's experiment on stock options reveal about the stock market? Options: A. That people are less likely to cheat when they are given a large amount of money, B. That people are more likely to cheat when they are given a large amount of money, C. That people are less likely to cheat when they see others cheating around them, D. That people are more likely to cheat when they see others cheating around them Correct Option: D
Question 14: What did the speaker learn from his experience with the nurses about the importance of testing intuitions? Options: A. That our intuitions are always right and should not be questioned, B. That our intuitions are often wrong and should be tested, C. That our intuitions are irrelevant to decision-making, D. That our intuitions are the only way to make decisions Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Question: According to Ariely, when someone in "your group" is cheating, what behavior are you most likely to exhibit?
Options: A. You will cheat as well, B. You will reprimand the person for cheating, C. You will be more honest, D. You will block the person on facebook
Correct Option: A

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: According to Ariely, why should we carry out systematic experimentation of our intuition?
Options: A. Because many of our intuitions are wrong, B. So we can do better in the world, C. Because we always think our intuition is right, D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

That the patient's pain was irrelevant to the decision Correct Option: B
Question 3: What did the speaker's experiment on cheating reveal about human behavior? Options: A. That people are generally honest and trustworthy, B. That people cheat only when they think they can get away with it, C. That people cheat more when they are given a personal fudge factor, D. That people cheat just a little bit, and are influenced by social norms and distance from money Correct Option: D

A factor that increases the likelihood of cheating, C. A factor that decreases the likelihood of cheating, D. A factor that has no effect on cheating behavior Correct Option: A

That the experiment had no effect on cheating behavior Correct Option: B

That our intuitions are often wrong and should be tested, C. That our intuitions are irrelevant to decision-making, D. That our intuitions are the only way to make decisions Correct Option: B

That people cheat less when they see others cheating around them, C. That people cheat equally when they see others cheating around them, D. That the experiment had no effect on cheating behavior Correct Option: A

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: According to Schwartz, what did President Obama appeal to in his first inaugural address?
Options: A. Trust in our country, B. Our need to invest in the economy, C. Our virtue, D. Our childish nature
Correct Option: C

They need to learn to respect themselves, others, and learning, B. They need to learn to be smart and knowledgeable, C. They need to learn to be kind and empathetic, D. They need to learn to be rich and successful Correct Option: A
Question 8: According to the transcript, what is the virtue that we need above all others, and why? Options: A. It's kindness and empathy, because it's what allows us to connect with others, B. It's practical wisdom, because it allows us to display other virtues like honesty and courage at the right time and in the right way, C. It's courage, because it's what allows us to take risks and face challenges, D. It's honesty, because it's what allows us to be truthful and transparent Correct Option: B
Question 9: According to the transcript, what is the importance of paying attention to the structure of the organizations within which we work? Options: A. It's because it allows us to be more efficient and productive, B. It's because it allows us to be more creative and innovative, C. It enables us and other people to develop wisdom rather than having it suppressed, D. It's because it allows us to be more comfortable and happy Correct Option: C
Question 10: According to the transcript, what is the speaker working on, and why? Options: A. The speaker is working on a way to make machines more intelligent and autonomous, B. The speaker is working on a way to detect signs of trouble in machines using predictive analytics, C. The speaker is working on a way to make people more virtuous and wise, D. The speaker is working on a way to make organizations more efficient and productive Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What are some sentiments that Barry Schwartz shares with the TED audience?
Options: A. You don't need to be brilliant to be wise, B. You should be mentored by amateurs, C. You need very little experience to learn how to care for people, D. If you are brilliant, you don't need wisdom
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What did Barack Obama appeal to in his inaugural address, instead of just telling people to "go shopping" or "trust your country"? Options: A. The importance of being happy, B. The need to put aside childish things and appeal to virtue, C. The value of being rich, D. The necessity of following rules Correct Option: B
Question 2: According to the transcript, what is the job description of a hospital janitor like? Options: A. It involves a lot of human interaction and empathy, B. It's a highly technical job that requires a lot of specialized knowledge, C. It doesn't involve human interaction and is all about following rules, D. It's a job that can be done in a mortuary just as easily as in a hospital Correct Option: D
Question 3: What did the psychologists discover when they interviewed hospital janitors to get a sense of what they thought their jobs were like? Options: A. They thought their jobs were all about following rules and procedures, B. They thought their jobs involved a lot of human interaction and empathy, C. They thought their jobs were all about being technical and specialized, D. They didn't think their jobs were interesting or important Correct Option: B
Question 4: According to the transcript, what is the difference between moral will and moral skill? Options: A. Moral will is about following rules and procedures, while moral skill is about being technical and specialized, B. Moral will is about having the desire to do the right thing, while moral skill is about knowing how to do the right thing, C. Moral will is about being kind and empathetic, while moral skill is about being clever and resourceful, D. Moral will is about being smart and knowledgeable, while moral skill is about being practical and wise Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the problem with relying too heavily on rules and incentives, according to the transcript? Options: A. They can be too complex and difficult to understand, B. They can be too simple and easy to follow, C. They can deprive people of the opportunity to improvise and learn from their mistakes, D. They can only be used in certain situations, such as in medicine or business Correct Option: C
Question 6: According to the transcript, what is the difference between moral heroes and ordinary heroes? Options: A. Moral heroes are people who do extraordinary things, while ordinary heroes are people who do ordinary things, B. Moral heroes are people who are guided by nature, while ordinary heroes have to work at it, C. Moral heroes are people who do things for personal gain, while ordinary heroes do things for the greater good, D. Moral heroes are people who are celebrated and admired, while ordinary heroes are not Correct Option: A
Question 7: What did KIPP realize was the single most important thing that kids need to learn, according to the transcript? Options: A. They need to learn to respect themselves, others, and learning, B. They need to learn to be smart and knowledgeable, C. They need to learn to be kind and empathetic, D. They need to learn to be rich and successful Correct Option: A
Question 8: According to the transcript, what is the virtue that we need above all others, and why? Options: A. It's kindness and empathy, because it's what allows us to connect with others, B. It's practical wisdom, because it allows us to display other virtues like honesty and courage at the right time and in the right way, C. It's courage, because it's what allows us to take risks and face challenges, D. It's honesty, because it's what allows us to be truthful and transparent Correct Option: B
Question 9: According to the transcript, what is the importance of paying attention to the structure of the organizations within which we work? Options: A. It's because it allows us to be more efficient and productive, B. It's because it allows us to be more creative and innovative, C. It enables us and other people to develop wisdom rather than having it suppressed, D. It's because it allows us to be more comfortable and happy Correct Option: C
Question 10: According to the transcript, what is the speaker working on, and why? Options: A. The speaker is working on a way to make machines more intelligent and autonomous, B. The speaker is working on a way to detect signs of trouble in machines using predictive analytics, C. The speaker is working on a way to make people more virtuous and wise, D. The speaker is working on a way to make organizations more efficient and productive Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 8. 

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. The ground truth MCQ asks about the sentiments that Barry Schwartz shares with the TED audience, and one of the correct options is "You don't need to be brilliant to be wise." Question 8 asks about the virtue that we need above all others and why, and the correct option is "It's practical wisdom, because it allows us to display other virtues like honesty and courage at the right time and in the right way." This option is closely related to the idea that you don't need to be brilliant to be wise, as practical wisdom is the key to displaying other virtues.

However, an even more similar question is not present among the options. But among the given options, question 8 has the closest match in terms of wisdom and brilliance.

But if we consider the context of brilliance and wisdom, then Question 1 also has a similar match where it says that Barack Obama appealed to virtue in his inaugural address, instead of just telling people to "go shopping" or "trust your country", this has the context of wisdom over brilliance or other factors.

However the closest match is with Question 8.

ordinary if not extraordinary heroes as heads of organizations we should strive to create environments that encourage and nurture both moral skill and moral will even the wisest and most well-meaning descriptions like the job description of the janitors because the truth is that any work you do that involves interaction with other people is moral work and any moral work depends upon practical wisdom and perhaps most important as teachers we should strive to be the ordinary heroes the moral exemplars to the people we mentor and there are a few things that we have to remember as teachers one **Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: According to Schwartz, what quality describes a wise person?
Options: A. When and how to make "the exception to every rule", B. When and how to improvise, C. How to use moral skills in the service of the right aims, D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

Question 1: What did Barack Obama appeal to in his inaugural address, instead of just telling people to "go shopping" or "trust your country"? Options: A. The importance of being happy, B. The need to put aside childish things and appeal to virtue, C. The value of being rich, D. The necessity of following rules Correct Option: B
Question 2: According to the transcript, what is the job description of a hospital janitor like? Options: A. It involves a lot of human interaction and empathy, B. Moral will is about being kind and empathetic, while moral skill is about being clever and resourceful, D. Moral will is about being smart and knowledgeable, while moral skill is about being practical and wise Correct Option: B

They can only be used in certain situations, such as in medicine or business Correct Option: C

Moral heroes are people who do extraordinary things, while ordinary heroes are people who do ordinary things, B. Moral heroes are people who are guided by nature, while ordinary heroes have to work at it, C. Moral heroes are people who do things for personal gain, while ordinary heroes do things for the greater good, D. Moral heroes are people who are celebrated and admired, while ordinary heroes are not Correct Option: A

It's courage, because it's what allows us to take risks and face challenges, D. It's honesty, because it's what allows us to be truthful and transparent Correct Option: B
Question 9: According to the transcript, what is the importance of paying attention to the structure of the organizations within which we work? Options: A. It's because it allows us to be more efficient and productive, B. It's because it allows us to be more creative and innovative, C. It enables us and other people to develop wisdom rather than having it suppressed, D. It's because it allows us to be more comfortable and happy Correct Option: C

Jones was out of his bed getting a little exercise trying to build up his strength walking slowly up and down the hall and Charlene told them about how she ignored her supervisors admonition didn't their job duties in the service of other objectives a wise person knows how to improvise as Luke did when he rewashed the floor real-world problems are often ambiguous and ill-defined and the context to fail and to learn from your failures and you need to be mentored by wise teachers when you ask the janitors who behave like the ones I described how hard it is to learn to do their jobs they tell you that it takes lots of experience and they don't mean it takes lots of experience to learn how to mop floors and empty trash cans it takes lots of experience to learn how to care for people at Ted brilliance is rampant it's scary the good news is that you don't need to be brilliant to be wise the bad news is that without wisdom brilliance isn't enough it's as likely to get you into trouble and other people into trouble as anything else now I hope that we all know this there's a sense in which it's obvious and yet let me tell you a little story it's a story about lemonade a dad and his 11 year old son were watching a Detroit Tigers game at the ballpark his son asked him for some lemonade and dad went to the concession stand to buy it all they had was Mike's Hard Lemonade which was 5% alcohol dad being an academic had no idea that Mike's Hard Lemonade was it contained out at all so we brought it back and the kid was drinking it and a security guard spotted it and called the police who called an ambulance they rushed to the ballpark whisked the kid to the hospital the emergency room to ascertain that the kid had no alcohol in his blood and they were ready to let the kid go but not so fast the Wayne County Child Welfare protective agency said oh and the child was sent to a foster home for three days at that point can the child go home well a judge said yes but only if the dad leaves the house and checks into a motel after two weeks I'm happy to report the family was reunited but the welfare workers and the ambulance people and the judge all said the same thing we hate to do it but we have to follow procedure how do things like this happen Scott Simon who told this story on NPR said rules and procedures may be dumb but they spare you from thinking and to be fair and to be fair rules are often imposed because previous officials have been lacks and they let a child go back to an abusive household fair enough when things go wrong as of course they do we reach for two tools to try to fix them one tool we reach for is rules better ones more of them the second tool we reach for is incentives better ones more of them what else after all is there we can certainly see this in response to the current financial crisis regulate regulate regulate fix the incentives fix the incentives fix the incentives the truth is that neither rules nor incentives are enough to do the job how could you even write a rule that got the janitors to do what they did and would you pay them a bonus for being empathic it's preposterous on its face and what happens is that as we turn increasingly to rules rules and incentives may make things better in the short run but they create a downward spiral that makes them worse in the long run moral skill is chipped away by an over reliance on rules that deprives us of the opportunity to improvise and learn from our improvisation and moral will is on mind by an incessant appeal to incentives that destroy our desire to do the right thing and without intending it by appealing to rules and incentives we are engaging in a war on wisdom let me just give you a few example first of rules and the war on moral skill the lemonade story is one second no doubt more familiar to you is the nature of modern American education scripted lockstep curriculum here's an example from Chicago kindergarten reading and enjoying literature and words that begin with B the baths assemble students on a rug give students a warning about the dangers of hot water say 75 items in this script to teach a 25 page picture book all over Chicago and every kindergarten class in the city every teacher is saying the same words in the same way on the same day we know why these scripts are there we don't trust the judgment of teachers enough to let them loose on their own scripts like these are insurance policies against disaster and they prevent disaster but what they assure in its place is mediocrity don't get me wrong we need rules jazz musicians need some notes most of them need some notes on the page we need more rules for the bankers god knows but too many rules prevent accomplished jazz musicians from improvising and as a result they lose their gifts or worse they stop playing all together now how about incentives they seem clever if you have one reason for doing something and I give you a second reason for doing the same thing it seems only logical that two reasons are better than one and you're more likely to do it right well not always sometimes two reasons to do the same thing seem to compete with one another instead of complementing and they make people less likely to do it I'll just give you one example because time is racing in Switzerland back in about 15 years ago they were trying to decide where to cite nuclear waste dumps there was going to be a national referendum and some psychologists went around and polled citizens who were very well informed and they said would you be willing to have a nuclear waste dump in your community astonishingly 50% of the citizens said yes they knew it or thought it was dangerous they thought it would reduce their property values but it had to go somewhere and they had responsibilities as citizens the psychologists asked other people a slightly different question they said if we paid you six weeks salary every year would you be willing to have a nuclear waste dump in your community two reasons it's my responsibility and I'm getting paid instead of 50% saying yes 25% said yes what happens is that the second this introduction of the incentive gets us so that instead of asking what are my responsibilities all we ask is what serves my interests when incentives don't work when CEOs ignore the long-term health of their companies in pursuit of short-term gains that will lead to massive bonuses the response is always the same get smarter incentives the truth is that there are no incentives you can devise that are ever going to be smart enough any incentive system can be subverted by bad will we need incentives people have to make a living but excessive reliance on incentives demoralizes professional activity in two senses of that word it causes people who engage in that activity to lose morale and it causes the activity itself to lose morality Barack Obama said before he was inaugurated we must ask not just as it profitable but is it right and when professions are demoralized everyone in them becomes dependent on addicted to incentives and they stop asking is it right we see this in medicine and we certainly see it in the world of business it is obvious that this is not the way people want to do their work so what can we do a few sources of hope we ought to try to Reem oral eyes work one way not to do it teach more ethics courses there is no better way to show people that you're not serious than to tie up everything you have to say about ethics into a little package with a bow and consign it to the margins as an
